data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>quit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "Hey, you going <vocabulary>to quit</vocabulary>?" "<reading>Yah</reading> (<ja>や</ja>) man, I'm going to quit."

context_sentences.en: I followed the doctor's advice and quit my job.
context_sentences.ja: 医者のアドバイスにしたがって、仕事を辞めました。

context_sentences.en: Who said Michael resigned as chief editor?
context_sentences.ja: マイケルがへん集長を辞めたなんて、だれが言ったの？

context_sentences.en: Since Fugu quit the company, I’m thinking about getting him a swim ring as a farewell gift. If anyone wants to join in on my idea, let me know.
context_sentences.ja: フグが会社を辞めるので、お餞別に浮き輪を買おうと思っています。一緒に買いたい人は連絡ください。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>quit</kanji> your current <kanji>generation</kanji> to join an older one you need all the <vocabulary>flattery</vocabulary> you can get because you're starting to feel old. People probably still won't like you though, ya old fart.

This word usually has <ja>お</ja> on the beginning, as in <ja>お世辞</ja>. Flattery is honorific after all, right?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Koichi is not good at giving insincere compliments.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは心にもないお世辞を言うのが下手です。

context_sentences.en: I don't like being complimented on my Japanese speaking.
context_sentences.ja: お世辞で日本語が上手だと言われるのは好きではありません。

context_sentences.en: "Oh wow! You look so beautiful tonight. Like a princess!" "Flattery will get you nowhere, daddy.”
context_sentences.ja: 「わぉ！今夜の君はとてもきれいだね。まるで、お姫様みたいだよ。」「パパ、お世辞を言っても何も出ないわよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an <ja>い</ja> on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>far</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>far</vocabulary> (or it's <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic: You want to go <vocabulary>far</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>far away</vocabulary> when you see a <reading>toe... oh</reading> (<ja>とお</ja>)! You realize there is a zombie toe on the ground and it reminds you of where you can go that's far from here—where the zombie that once had this toe went! (Remember the kanji mnemonic? It's that scooter zombie's toe that makes you say oh and want to go.)

context_sentences.en: Koichi's apartment is located about three hours from the Tofugu office, in some faraway woods.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチのアパートはトーフグオフィスから三時間ほど行った、遠い林の中にあります。

context_sentences.en: That newly-built condo was really nice but we gave up on buying it, because it was too far from the station.
context_sentences.ja: あの新築マンション、とてもよかったんですけど、駅から遠すぎて買うのをあきらめました。

context_sentences.en: How far is Tokyo from Portland? Is it too far for me to walk?
context_sentences.ja: 東京は、ポートランドからどれくらい遠いんですか？歩くにはちょっと遠すぎますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you are able to <kanji>enter</kanji> the <kanji>gate</kanji> then you have gained <vocabulary>admission</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>entrance</vocabulary> to the facility.  Sometimes you do this to start an <vocabulary>apprenticeship</vocabulary>, where you get an <vocabulary>introduction</vocabulary> to some sweet new skills, like how to make an entrance.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I heard that Koichi is going to be a pupil of the famous kendo master.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは有名な剣道の先生のところに入門するそうですよ。

context_sentences.en: I haven't completed the admissions procedure yet.
context_sentences.ja: 入門手つづきをまだ終えていません。

context_sentences.en: Once you stick the alligator head onto the crab, the WaniKani figurine will be complete. This concludes the introductory course in 3D printing.
context_sentences.ja: ワニの頭をカニにくっつけたらワニカニのフィギュアが出来上がります。これで3Dプリンティングの入門コースが終了になります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>関</ja> means <kanji>related</kanji>. So, when you add <ja>する</ja> to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to be related to</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: There is no room for compromise on this matter.
context_sentences.ja: このことに関しては、妥協のよ地はありません。

context_sentences.en: Sayaka is conducting research on Japanese literature.
context_sentences.ja: サヤカは、日本文学に関する研究を行っている。

context_sentences.en: While working at the Tofugu office, Viet received a call related to a shooting at his hideout.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは、トーフグのオフィスで働いている時に、アジトでの発砲に関する電話を受けた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>connection</kanji> <kanji>related</kanji> to another <kanji>connection</kanji> obviously has some kind of <vocabulary>connection</vocabulary>, at least between all those meanings.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Viet is a yakuza, but I can say for sure that he is not connected to that crime.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトはヤクザだが、そのはんざいには関係してないとだん言できます。

context_sentences.en: Viet is wondering if he should cut his connections with the yakuza and just focus on his work at Tofugu.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは、ヤクザとの関係をたってトーフグの仕事に専念するかどうかまよっています。

context_sentences.en: "He’s been married before and has three kids." "I know, but that has nothing to do with it."
context_sentences.ja: 「彼は前に結婚していて、子供も3人もいるのよ。」「知ってるわよ。でも、それとこれとは関係ないでしょ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>slope</kanji>s of the <kanji>god</kanji>s! What could this be? Well, it's mainly just a company, known as <vocabulary>Hanshin</vocabulary>. They're based in the area between Osaka and Kobe. Think of it this way: <ja>大阪</ja> + <ja>神戸</ja> = <ja>阪神</ja>! They're everywhere, though, and even have a baseball team (the Hanshin Tigers), so it's good to know.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I'm setting the Hanshin Electric Railway colored jelly by cooling it with ice.
context_sentences.ja: 阪神電車カラーのゼリーを氷でひやして固めているところです。

context_sentences.en: I am thinking about buying a newly-built house in the Hanshin district. About how much is the market price?
context_sentences.ja: 今度、阪神地区に新築の家を買おうと思ってるんですが、相場はいくらぐらいなんですか。

context_sentences.en: Oh my God! Hanshin Tigers fans dived off the Ebisu bridge down into the dirty river? Wow, they are nuts!
context_sentences.ja: うわぁ、阪神タイガースのファンたち、恵比寿橋からあの汚い川にダイブしたんだって？すげぇな、あいつらの頭大丈夫かよ！

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>front</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>front</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>front side</vocabulary> of it (kind of like how <ja>外面</ja> is the exterior because it's the outside face). This also means <vocabulary>fore</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>forefront</vocabulary>, especially when used metaphorically.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Please find a box that has green on both the front and back sides.
context_sentences.ja: 前面も後面も両方とも緑色の箱をさがしてください。

context_sentences.en: Whenever we send a letter or a package, we put the Tofugu sticker on the front of it.
context_sentences.ja: 手紙や小包を送る時には、いつも前面にトーフグのステッカーを貼ります。

context_sentences.en: At this time, Viet came to stand at the forefront of the movement to make Taco Day a national holiday.
context_sentences.ja: この時、ビエトは「タコスの日」を祭日にしようという運動の前面に立つようになった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>ground</kanji>/<kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> is the surface that makes up the <vocabulary>ground</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>Earth's surface</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>面</ja> is what you'd expect. <ja>地</ja> on the other hand is <ja>じ</ja>, which is a bit different (though close sounding) to what you learned previously. Thank the Chinese and their ever changing language for this one. Think of <reading>Je</reading>sus laying on the ground, telling you how comfortable the ground is. You say "Jesus, you have to get off the ground, you have a dinner to go to," but he doesn't want to leave.

context_sentences.en: Fugu said that he'd rather live underground than underwater.
context_sentences.ja: 海の中じゃなくて地面の中に住めたらいいのに、とフグは言いました。

context_sentences.en: Our front yard doesn't have any grass, so the earth's surface gets really hot during summer.
context_sentences.ja: 家の前の庭は草が生えていないので、夏の間は地面がとても熱くなります。

context_sentences.en: Koichi gently stroked Fugu and placed him on the ground.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはフグを優しく撫でてから、地面に降ろしてあげました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>face</kanji> to something is the <vocabulary>exterior</vocabulary> of that thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This reading is usually for building exteriors and outside surfaces. The other reading <ja>そとづら</ja> is used when a person's personality comes to the surface and is a bit of an exception, so you'll probably see it less often. Just keep those differences in mind!

context_sentences.en: On the surface, Viet looks like a nice guy, but he actually has a scary side.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは外面はいい人そうですが、実はとてもおそろしい一面を持っています。

context_sentences.en: The exterior of Koichi-sama's new kabuto helmet has been finished with gold lacquer, so it should be easy to care for.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチ様の新しいかぶとの外面は金のラッカーで仕上げられたので、お手入れはしやすいはずです。

context_sentences.en: You shouldn’t be fooled by his outward appearance. I hated my instructor because he showed his superiors a nice face while he bullied subordinates, including me, behind their backs.
context_sentences.ja: 彼の外面に騙されない方がいいですよ。私がインストラクターのことが嫌いだったのは、上司にはいい顔をして陰で後輩のことを小突き回していたからです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>surface</kanji> of a <kanji>drawing</kanji> is a <vocabulary>screen</vocabulary>. Just imagine your computer screen. On its surface is a drawing, right? It just happens to move around all the time, but it's still a screen!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: If you stare at computer screens for a long time, your eyesight will get worse.
context_sentences.ja: ずっとコンピューターの画面ばかり見ていると目が悪くなるよ。

context_sentences.en: Lately, an obscene image of dogs keeps automatically appearing on our monitor, so yeah, we're having some issues.
context_sentences.ja: 最近、よく犬のエッチな画像が自動で画面に出てくるからみんなこまっているんだよね。

context_sentences.en: It’s weird. Viet is sitting glued to a screen for hours as usual, though his actual screen has been completely black since this morning.
context_sentences.ja: 変なんだよ。ビエトはいつも通り画面に釘付けになって何時間も座ったままでいるんだけど、肝心の画面は今朝から真っ黒なんだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: I have something to talk to you about face-to-face. When are you available?
context_sentences.ja: あなたに、面と向かってお話したいことがあります。ご予定は、いつが空いていますか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>face</kanji> of this object is so <kanji>white</kanji>! Why is it so white compared to everything else? This is so <vocabulary>interesting</vocabulary>...
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is unlike what you've learned before, at least with the <ja>面</ja> part (<ja>白い</ja> is just like the vocab word <ja>白い</ja>). When you look at the white face of the object you say to your friend Moe: "<reading>Oh mo</reading>!" (<ja>おも</ja>) because you want him to come over and look at this. Try to imagine someone you know named Moe, or at least a celebrity or something named Moe.

context_sentences.en: He is an amusing guy, his only downside is that he gets angry over the smallest things.
context_sentences.ja: あいつは面白いやつだけど、ちょっとしたことですぐ切れるのがネックだよな。

context_sentences.en: This manga is a bit crude but it's very interesting.
context_sentences.ja: このマンガは、ちょっと下品だけどとても面白いんです。

context_sentences.en: Ahahaha! You crack me up, Fugu! That’s the funniest thing I’ve ever heard.
context_sentences.ja: あはははは！超ウケるんだけど。今まで聞いた中で、一番面白い話だわ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>public building</kanji> where <kanji>writte</kanji>n things are all <kanji>diagram</kanji>ed out in a way that lets you find said written things? That sounds like a <vocabulary>library</vocabulary> to me!
data.reading_mnemonic: The <ja>書館</ja> part should be readable by you, but it's the <ja>図</ja> that's troublesome with an alternate reading from the one you learned. Imagine yourself at the library. You check out every single book you can about the human <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>). You have a giant stack of books on it, then you drop it... ironically on your toe. You decide to <reading>show Khan</reading> (your buddy) your smashed toe.

context_sentences.en: Did you know that you can even borrow ebooks from the library?
context_sentences.ja: 図書館から、電子書せきをかりることもできるって知っていましたか。

context_sentences.en: If you go straight, you'll see the library's bathroom at the end of this aisle ahead.
context_sentences.ja: この図書館のトイレは、ここを真っ直ぐ行ったところの一番おくにあります。

context_sentences.en: "When is your New Year's vacation? I want to go to the library with you." "I have five days off starting December 30th, but I’m afraid the library will be closed too."
context_sentences.ja: 「年末年始のお休みいつからいつまでなの？一緒に図書館に行こうよ。」「十二月三十日から五日間だけど、図書館も閉まってるはずだよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>消化</ja> is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is <vocabulary>to digest</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you know <ja>消化</ja> you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

context_sentences.en: It looks like this cat couldn't digest the fish skin and threw it up.
context_sentences.ja: このネコは、魚の皮をうまく消化できずにはいてしまったみたいです。

context_sentences.en: Tofugu recommends that all employees use up all their paid days off.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグは、全社員が有きゅう休かを完全消化することをすいしょうしています。

context_sentences.en: I just ate 100 pieces of fugu sashimi. It’s gonna take a while to digest. (Burp)
context_sentences.ja: 今、フグの刺し身を百切れ食べたよ。消化するのにちょっと時間がかかりそう。(ゲップ)

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that <ja>消す</ja> is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary> on its own. How can you differentiate this from <ja>消す</ja>? Well, <ja>える</ja> allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin <reading>air</reading> (<ja>える</ja>). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it <vocabulary>to disappear</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from <ja>消す</ja>, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a <reading>key</reading> (<ja>き</ja>) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical <reading>key</reading>.

context_sentences.en: WaniKani makes most of my income disappear.
context_sentences.ja: ワニカニにしゅう入の大半が消えます。

context_sentences.en: My eyebrows have worn off from my sweat.
context_sentences.ja: あせでまゆ毛が消えてしまいました。

context_sentences.en: He waved goodbye until she completely disappeared from view.
context_sentences.ja: 彼は、彼女が視界から完全に消えるまで、さようならと手を振り続けた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <ja>気持ち</ja> (feeling) is <kanji>bad</kanji>. So, you can imagine how you feel isn't good, it's a <vocabulary>bad feeling</vocabulary>. You're <vocabulary>feeling terrible</vocabulary>, in fact.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words <ja>気持ち</ja> and <ja>悪い</ja>. Hopefully you've seen both and can combine them together to know the reading automatically. No bad feelings with this word, right?

context_sentences.en: I'm hungover, I have a bad headache, and I feel terrible. This is awful.
context_sentences.ja: 二日よいで、頭はガンガンするし、めっちゃ気持ち悪いし、最悪だよ。

context_sentences.en: Koichi called out to Viet with his sickly sweet voice.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは気持ち悪いネコなで声で、ビエトをよんだ。

context_sentences.en: Stop bending your arms like that. It’s seriously weirding me out.
context_sentences.ja: ちょっと、そんな風に腕を曲げるのやめてくれない？めちゃくちゃ気持ち悪いんだけど。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>stream</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>to stream</vocabulary> (though it's also <vocabulary>to flow</vocabulary>, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from <ja>流す</ja> because with <ja>流す</ja> you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) the toilet maker. With <ja>流れる</ja> you find a <reading>rare</reading> (<ja>れる</ja>) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>流す</ja>. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

context_sentences.en: After the bicycle race, sweat was streaming down Viet's face.
context_sentences.ja: 自転車のレースの後、ビエトの顔をあせがたきのように流れていました。

context_sentences.en: Which area does this river flow through?
context_sentences.ja: この川は、どの地いきを流れているんですか？

context_sentences.en: I like the sound of flowing water, so just let your tears stream down your cheeks. See? It’s so beautiful.
context_sentences.ja: 流れる水の音が好きなので、涙が君の頬を流れるままにしておいてくれよ。ほら、とても美しいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>動く</ja> hopefully, and know it means <vocabulary>to move</vocabulary>. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go <vocabulary>to move something</vocabulary> the thing you're moving starts to <reading>cuss</reading> (<ja>かす</ja>) you out because it's angry.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this can come from <ja>動く</ja>. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

context_sentences.en: Almost all of my friends can push and move a truck with their hands.
context_sentences.ja: 友だちのほとんどが、トラックを手でおして動かすことができるよ。

context_sentences.en: Koichi suddenly got up, started sleepwalking, and tried to move the massive grand piano.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチったら、急にむくっと起き上がって、ねぼけてあのきょ大なグランドピアノを動かそうとしだしたんだよ。

context_sentences.en: I can’t move my legs anymore because of that motorcycle accident.
context_sentences.ja: あのバイク事故のせいで、もう脚を動かすことができなくなっちゃったんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: <ja>着る</ja> (to wear), <ja>着く</ja> (to arrive), and now <ja>着ける</ja> (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to <ja>着る</ja>, right? In this case, this word is like <ja>付ける</ja>, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is <vocabulary>to put on</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to wear</vocabulary>. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>着く</ja>'s reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with <ja>付ける</ja>, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc!

context_sentences.en: I wore earrings for the first time in a long time.
context_sentences.ja: 久しぶりにイヤリングを着けてみた。

context_sentences.en: Koichi has fun by secluding himself in his room and putting on masks from around the world every night.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチのしゅ味は、夜な夜な自分の部屋にこもって世界かく地のお面を着けてあそぶことです。

context_sentences.en: Could you promise me that you will wear this good luck charm all the time, please?
context_sentences.ja: このお守りを肌身離さず身に着けると約束してくれないか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>勉強</ja> (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is <vocabulary>to study</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>勉強</ja>. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

context_sentences.en: It's important to log into WaniKani and study kanji every day.
context_sentences.ja: 毎日ワニカニにログインしてかん字を勉強することが大事です。

context_sentences.en: I like to study but I don't like to read.
context_sentences.ja: 勉強することは好きなんですが、本を読むことはきらいなんです。

context_sentences.en: I’m too busy and I just don’t have enough time to study Einstein’s theory of relativity.
context_sentences.ja: ちょっと忙し過ぎて、アインシュタインの相対性理論について勉強する時間がないだけなんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>旅行</ja> by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's <vocabulary>to travel</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take a trip</vocabulary>. These are fun to do. You should do them!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>旅行</ja>, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

context_sentences.en: Not only is Aya traveling to South Korea, but she's also traveling to Japan.
context_sentences.ja: アヤはかん国を旅行するだけでなく、日本にも旅行する予定です。

context_sentences.en: I went to a hair salon before taking my trip, but it ended up shorter than I'd wanted.
context_sentences.ja: 旅行する前に美よう院に行ったんだけど、思ってたより短く切られちゃったんだよね。

context_sentences.en: Seriously, it’s already been a week since our trip together and he hasn’t called me back. I must have farted too many times while I was sleeping.
context_sentences.ja: マジ、終わってる。一緒に旅行をした後、彼が一週間も電話を折り返してこないの。きっと、私寝っ屁をこきまくってたんだわ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that the kanji <ja>温</ja> means <kanji>warm</kanji>, and this verb is related. It means <vocabulary>to heat something up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to warm something up</vocabulary>. It's all about you doing something to another object to make it hot, like putting it in the microwave.
data.reading_mnemonic: The kanji reading is the same as <ja>温かい</ja>. As long as you know that word, you should be able to associate that reading with this word.

context_sentences.en: Please don't heat that bowl in the microwave.
context_sentences.ja: その器は電子レンジで温めないでください。

context_sentences.en: Before I go to bed, I like to heat up milk and drink it.
context_sentences.ja: 夜ねる前に牛乳を温めてホットミルクにして飲むのが好きです。

context_sentences.en: Kombu seaweed releases its sweet flavor when it’s soaked in water and heated up.
context_sentences.ja: 水に入れて温めると、昆布のうまみ成分がしみ出てきます。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen <ja>起きる</ja> which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word <vocabulary>to wake someone up</vocabulary>. How do you differentiate between this and <ja>起きる</ja>? Because of the <ja>す</ja> on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you, making you wish you never woke them up.

This can also mean <vocabulary>to cause something</vocabulary>. I guess if you wake someone up and they're not a morning person, you could cause something... like trouble.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>起きる</ja>, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

context_sentences.en: I tried really hard to wake you up, but it didn't work.
context_sentences.ja: 折角起こしてあげたのに、意味なかったね。

context_sentences.en: We don't want to wake our sleeping baby, so please don't buzz the intercom.
context_sentences.ja: 赤ちゃんを起こしたくないので、インターホンは鳴らさないでください。

context_sentences.en: That person caused a problem at work and got fired.
context_sentences.ja: その人、仕事で問題を起こして、首になったんだよ。

context_sentences.en: You are absolutely correct, Viet! We should definitely wake Koichi up right now!
context_sentences.ja: ビエットが100%正しいよ。今すぐコウイチ起こすべきだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that <ja>旅行</ja> is "trip." So who is <kanji>someone</kanji> who goes on trips? That is a <vocabulary>tourist</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>traveler</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of <ja>旅行</ja> already.

context_sentences.en: At first, I thought the traveler was unsociable, but when I tried talking to her, I discovered she was actually very interesting.
context_sentences.ja: 最初、ぶあい想な旅行者だなぁと思ったんだけど、話をしてみると意外におも白い人だったのよね。

context_sentences.en: Normally we would not do this, but since you are a tourist, we'll comply with your request.
context_sentences.ja: ふだんはこういった対おうはいたしませんが、旅行者でいらっしゃるということですので、今回は特別に対おうさせていただきます。

context_sentences.en: Hey, look, look. Don’t you think that tourist is wearing clothes that are completely unsuitable for her age?
context_sentences.ja: ねぇ、見て見て。あの旅行者の服装、全然年相応じゃないと思わない？

data.meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>bad</kanji> <kanji>mouth</kanji> is <vocabulary>saying bad things</vocabulary> (as usual!). Everything that comes out of this bad mouth of yours is <vocabulary>verbal abuse</vocabulary>. One day someone's going to pop you in that bad mouth of yours.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings for these two kanji, probably because this word is just two words put together into one (bad + mouth). Use your knowledge of the vocab words <ja>悪い</ja> and <ja>口</ja> to learn the reading of this word.

Okay, I lied. You can also do <ja>わるぐち</ja> if you want. Sorry to say such bad things before.

context_sentences.en: Viet started shouting verbal abuse at Koichi with a malicious grin.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは意地悪なえみをうかべながらコウイチに大声で悪口を言い始めた。

context_sentences.en: I've never bad mouthed my husband in front of my kids.
context_sentences.ja: 子どもの前では、おっとの悪口を言ったことがありません。

context_sentences.en: I heard that all of my friends were saying bad things about me.
context_sentences.ja: 友達がみんなで私の悪口を言っているのを聞いちゃったんだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>good</kanji> is <vocabulary>bad</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>substandard</vocabulary>. This usage is more formal and frequently paired with other kanji compounds. Alternatively, it can refer to someone who is a  <vocabulary>delinquent</vocabulary>, in which case it is often used as a standalone word.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

context_sentences.en: It feels like Viet kind of has bad-boy hair today, don't you think?
context_sentences.ja: ビエト、今日はちょっと不良な感じのかみがただね。

context_sentences.en: Substandard potato chips were sold at half price, so I bought one and ate it. Then I got diarrhea.
context_sentences.ja: ひんしつ不良のポテトチップスが半額で売ってたので買って食べたらおなかをこわしました。

context_sentences.en: That delinquent girl’s grades suddenly dropped drastically and then she joined a gang.
context_sentences.ja: あの不良少女は、急に成績が大幅に下がった後、ギャングの一員になったんです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>器用</ja> means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're <kanji>not</kanji> those things. When you're not dextrous, you're <vocabulary>clumsy</vocabulary> and when you're not skillful you're <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of <ja>不</ja> changes from <ja>ふ</ja> to <ja>ぶ</ja>. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of <reading>boo</reading>-boos (<ja>ぶ</ja>), get it?

context_sentences.en: My teens were the hardest years for an awkward person like me.
context_sentences.ja: 十代は、不器用な私にとって、とても大変な時期でした。

context_sentences.en: My clumsy assistant made very disgusting coffee with his clumsy hands, as usual.
context_sentences.ja: 不器用な助手が、不器用な手つきで、いつものようにクソ不味いコーヒーをいれてくれた。

context_sentences.en: My husband is strict and clumsy, but he’s an honest person.
context_sentences.ja: 私の主人は堅苦しくて不器用ですが、正直者です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The noun form of <kanji>request</kanji> (don't be tricked by the <ja>い</ja> on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to <vocabulary>a request</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like <ja>お願いします</ja>. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

context_sentences.en: Please! Help me!
context_sentences.ja: お願い！手伝って！

context_sentences.en: "Can you do me a favor...?" "Of course. Name it."
context_sentences.ja: 「ちょっとお願いがあるんだけど……。」「もちろん。言ってみて。」

context_sentences.en: Smaller companies take on new challenges more rapidly, so they probably won't mind if we request a job like this.
context_sentences.ja: 中小企業は小回りが利くから、こういう仕事をお願いしても平気だろう。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drink</kanji>ing <kanji>as much as you want</kanji> is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an <vocabulary>all you can drink</vocabulary> place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <ja>放題</ja> (<ja>ほうだい</ja>) and <ja>飲む</ja> (<ja>のむ</ja>). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: I wonder which one is a better deal, all you can eat or all you can drink?
context_sentences.ja: 食べ放題と飲み放題だったらどっちの方がおとくかな？

context_sentences.en: "Can you plan a drinking party, Kanae?" "Okay! What's the theme of the party?" "Well, it's for the presentation of Viet's cosplay collection that he bought in Japan." "Okay. Can we do it at a super cheap all-you-can-drink Izakaya?"
context_sentences.ja: 「カナエ、ちょっと飲み会をき画してくれない？」「おっけー！どんなテーマの飲み会？」「うーんと、ビエトが日本で買ってきたコスプレコレクションのおひろ目会なんだけど。」「分かった。めっちゃ安い飲み放題のい酒屋でもいい？」

context_sentences.en: "So, you went to an all you can drink place last night. Anything else?" "No, that’s about it."
context_sentences.ja: 「じゃあ、あなたは昨夜飲み放題に行っていた訳ですね。他には何かしましたか？」「いや、まあそんなところだよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>as much as you want</kanji>, you are getting an <vocabulary>all you can eat</vocabulary> deal.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading consists of the readings of <ja>食べる</ja> and <ja>放題</ja>. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

context_sentences.en: I feel like my memory of going to the all you can eat restaurant with you is growing distant.
context_sentences.ja: 一しょに食べ放題に行ったのが、とおい昔のような気がするよ。

context_sentences.en: I went to an all-you-can-eat cake cafe in Japan and I was actually able to eat more than I'd expected.
context_sentences.ja: 日本で、ケーキ食べ放題のカフェに行ってみたんですが、思っていたよりもたくさん食べられました。

context_sentences.en: Ok, the coast is clear. Let’s go get all you can eat yakiniku.
context_sentences.ja: よし、今がチャンスだ。さあ、焼き肉食べ放題へ行こう。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>good</kanji> <kanji>like</kanji> is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a <vocabulary>good</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>favorable</vocabulary> thing.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

context_sentences.en: Tofugu and the Japanese government have a good relationship.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグと日本せいふは、良好なかんけいをたもっています。

context_sentences.en: Dr. Koichi told me that it's biologically favorable to be a dirty-minded person who doesn't talk about it.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチ先生は、ムッツリスケベであることは生物学的に良好なことだっておっしゃってましたよ。

context_sentences.en: The patient has been doing well for the last six months and has been able to live a normal life.
context_sentences.ja: その患者さんの経過は過去六ヶ月間良好で、普段通りの生活を送ることができています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>kill</kanji> a <kanji>person</kanji> that's <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know <ja>人</ja>'s reading as a vocab word and <ja>殺す</ja>'s reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that <ja>ころし</ja> goes to <ja>ごろし</ja> due to rendaku.

context_sentences.en: If you commit murder, you must go to prison.
context_sentences.ja: 人殺しをしたら、刑務所に行かなければなりません。

context_sentences.en: I heard there was a murder in this neighborhood yesterday.
context_sentences.ja: 昨日、この近所で人殺しがあったそうです。

context_sentences.en: I thought it wouldn't be fun to lead a calculating life, so I'd just do whatever I please, but I ended up becoming a murderer before I knew it.
context_sentences.ja: 計算ずくの人生なんてつまらないと思って好き勝手していたら、いつの間にか人殺しになってたんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>殺人</ja> (murder) from level 13. So, <kanji>someone</kanji> who does <kanji>murder</kanji> is what? A <vocabulary>murderer</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: That killer made a terrible mistake while running away.
context_sentences.ja: その殺人者は、とう走中に大変な失ぱいをおかしてしまった。

context_sentences.en: I'd been suspected of being the murderer, but I was finally cleared.
context_sentences.ja: 殺人者とうたがわれていましたが、ついにようぎが晴れました。

context_sentences.en: Up until now, my friend’s life has been an epic struggle. He began his life as the baby of a murderer.
context_sentences.ja: 今の今まで、俺の友達の人生は信じられない苦難の連続でした。彼の人生は殺人者の子どもとして始まりました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>finger</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji> is the kind of <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, <ja>指</ja> and <ja>輪</ja>. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as <ja><reading>ゆびわ</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: I lost my precious ring and I feel awful.
context_sentences.ja: 大事な指輪を失くしてしまい、気分が晴れません。

context_sentences.en: I can't get this ring off of my finger.
context_sentences.ja: 指輪が指から外れなくなってしまいました。

context_sentences.en: "When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but words are just words."
context_sentences.ja: 「ボーナスが出たら、ダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってやるよ。」「あなたはいつも口先ばかりでしょ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ring</kanji> of gum (<ja>ゴム</ja>) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a <vocabulary>rubber band</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for <ja>輪</ja> is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is <ja>わ</ja>, making this word <ja><reading>わゴム</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: This elastic band is very durable.
context_sentences.ja: この輪ゴムはとても丈夫です。

context_sentences.en: They suspected I was the rubber band robber, but I've now been cleared of all charges.
context_sentences.ja: 輪ゴムどろぼうのうたがいをかけられていたが、ついに晴れの身となりました。

context_sentences.en: Oh my God, I just totally love your dress! So many colorful rubber band pictures printed on it, eh? I’ve never seen a dress like this before.
context_sentences.ja: わぁ！そのワンピマジで可愛い！カラフルな輪ゴムの絵がたくさんプリントしてあるんだね！そんなワンピ初めてみたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something with <kanji>reason</kanji> you're arranging it. That's why this is <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I really appreciate that you organized the bookshelf.
context_sentences.ja: 本だなを整理してくれたこと、大変感謝しています。

context_sentences.en: It takes a great deal of time and effort to arrange all of these documents.
context_sentences.ja: この書るいを全て整理するには、大変な時間と労力が必要である。

context_sentences.en: So let me get this straight. It’s okay for men to cheat, but not for women. Is that what you’re trying to say?
context_sentences.ja: ちょっと話を整理させてね。つまり、男の人が浮気をするのはいいけど、女の人がするのはだめってこと？それがあなたの言いたいこと？

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>arrange</kanji> something according to <kanji>reason</kanji>, the result is an <vocabulary>arrangement</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: This apartment's residents' rooms are all neatly arranged.
context_sentences.ja: このアパートの住民の部屋はみんなきちんと整理されています。

context_sentences.en: Organizing well is important.
context_sentences.ja: 整理整とんすることは大切です。

context_sentences.en: I organized the photos from my field trip.
context_sentences.ja: 修学旅行で撮った写真を整理しました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hopefully you've seen <ja>暗記</ja> before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>暗記</ja>. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

context_sentences.en: Kristen knows the lyrics of the Sailor Moon's theme song by heart.
context_sentences.ja: クリステンはセーラームーンのテーマ曲の歌しを暗記している。

context_sentences.en: I have to memorize every single line in the script by tomorrow.
context_sentences.ja: 明日までに、台本に書いてあるセリフを一つ残らず暗記しなければいけません。

context_sentences.en: Memorizing sentences is more efficient than memorizing words by themselves.
context_sentences.ja: 文を丸ごと暗記する方が、単語だけを暗記するより効率がいい。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen <ja>練習</ja>, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to practice</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word <ja>練習</ja>. You should be able to read this!

context_sentences.en: I practiced pronouncing the word "meat" for six hours yesterday.
context_sentences.ja: 昨日、肉って言葉の発音を六時間も練習したんだぜ。

context_sentences.en: I'm practicing the line in the play that goes, "I didn't raise you to be such an ungrateful child!"
context_sentences.ja: 「おんをあだで返すような子に育てたおぼえはないよ！」というしばいのセリフを言うのを練習しています。

context_sentences.en: "Dude, we were absolutely crushed." "Yeah, it was a complete failure. I guess we need more practice."
context_sentences.ja: 「俺達、惨敗しちまったな。」「ああ、惨敗しちまった。もっとたくさん練習しないとな。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>映る</ja> is "to be reflected." Now you're doing the reflecting, which is really projecting (light). That's why this word is <vocabulary>to project</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>映る</ja>. So long as you know the reading of <ja>映る</ja> you should be able to read this one too.

context_sentences.en: Can you start projecting slides onto the screen for me?
context_sentences.ja: スクリーンにスライドを映し始めてもらえますか？

context_sentences.en: Why don't we use this white wall as a screen to project the movie?
context_sentences.ja: この白いかべをスクリーン代わりにして映画を映すのはどうでしょう。

context_sentences.en: Only Viet knows that Koichi really likes seeing himself reflected full-length in the mirror.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトだけが、コウイチが鏡に全身を映すのが好きだということを知っている。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen <ja>料理</ja> and probably know it means "cooking." So, what is a <kanji>person</kanji> who does cooking? That is <vocabulary>a cook</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>chef</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: After reading Koichi’s letter, I hardened my resolve to become a cook.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチからの手紙を読んで、料理人になる決意を固めました。

context_sentences.en: The chef ruefully said, "If you don't like my food, just leave it."
context_sentences.ja: 料理人は、「料理が気に入らなかったら、残してくださっていいですよ」と悲しそうに言いました。

context_sentences.en: The chef grabbed the bottle opener hanging from the freezer door.
context_sentences.ja: その料理人は、冷凍庫のドアから栓抜きを剥ぎ取った。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>芸術</ja> is <kanji>art</kanji> so you'd think that <ja>芸術家</ja> would be something like "art house." Well, it's not. Think of it this way: Who is the person who works for "House Art"? It's the <vocabulary>artist</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I can't hide my wry smile at this artist's works.
context_sentences.ja: この芸術家の作品には、苦笑いがかくせません。

context_sentences.en: The artist asked his disciple to look after his house while he was away and left for Europe to study.
context_sentences.ja: その芸術家は、弟子に留守番をたのんで、ヨーロッパに留学しました。

context_sentences.en: How about running a marathon with a bunch of artists the month after next?
context_sentences.ja: 再来月のマラソン大会、芸術家達と一緒に参加するってのはどう？

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something that can <kanji>move</kanji> by its <kanji>self</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>automatic</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I'm planning to buy a fully-automatic front loading washing machine with my bonus.
context_sentences.ja: ボーナスで、全自動のフロントロードしきのせんたくきを買う予定です。

context_sentences.en: I set up my smartphone to automatically upload every single photo to the cloud.
context_sentences.ja: スマホでとった写しんは、全て自動でクラウドにアップロードしてほぞんされるようにせっ定しています。

context_sentences.en: It’s Tofugu policy that workers caught eating Koichi’s bacon without permission are automatically fired.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>remainder</kanji>, but you can't really "to remainder." What is something that's similar that would make sense? How about <vocabulary>to leave behind</vocabulary>. This is when you're actually doing the leaving behind too. For example, you eat some food and you leave behind your rice because you're a bad child. You can remember this because of <ja>す</ja>. Every time you leave some food behind your mom would <reading>sue</reading> you, because she was a terrible mom. Imagine this.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word can come from level 14 item <ja>残る</ja>. Associate the two in your mind and you'll be able to read both.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>hard</kanji> so the verb vocab version? <vocabulary>To make something hard</vocabulary>. You need to differentiate this from <ja>固まる</ja>, though, which means "to harden" (the hardening happens on its own). This word means "to make something hard," because you're doing the hardening. You can remember this because you want to make something hard. And to do that, you send special "<reading>mail</reading>" (<ja>める</ja>) to this thing you want to make hard, and this mail does that for you.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since the reading for <ja>固</ja> (<ja>かた</ja>) is different than the one you learned with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you:

Why would you want <vocabulary>to make something hard</vocabulary>? Obviously because you want to put it in a <reading>cata</reading>pult (<ja>かた</ja>). There's no point putting soft things in catapults, after all.

context_sentences.en: You can harden clay with heat.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>action</kanji> that takes place is something that shouldn't have happened (but it did). This is a <vocabulary>strange incident</vocabulary>. The difference between this and <ja>事変</ja> is that while <ja>事変</ja> can also be used to describe a strange incident, it also can be used to talk about another type of incident as well. For example, the "Manshuu Jihen" is the "Manshuu Incident." This word, <ja>変事</ja> is more just a strange or unusual incident.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.ja: トーフグに何か変事が起きたんじゃないかと、全ワニカニユーザーが心配していたんですよ。

context_sentences.en: I always get excited during that ominous silence that happens before an unusual incident.
context_sentences.ja: 私は変事の前の不気味な静けさにいつもワクワクする。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>建築</ja> is architecture. So, someone of <kanji>house</kanji> <kanji>architecture</kanji> is someone who does architecture. They are an <vocabulary>architect</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read <ja>建築</ja> already.

context_sentences.en: Dad is very proud of you because you became an architect.
context_sentences.ja: お父さん、あんたが建築家になったから、鼻が高いのよ。

context_sentences.en: The doctor incorrectly diagnosed the architect with stomach cancer.
context_sentences.ja: 医者は、その建築家をあやまって胃がんだとしんだんしました。

context_sentences.en: My house was designed by a famous architect.
context_sentences.ja: 私の家は有名な建築家によって設計されたんですよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>紀元後</ja> is "Common Era", or "anno Domini"? Well, this is the opposite because it has <kanji>before</kanji> (<ja>前</ja>) instead of <ja>後</ja>. It's <vocabulary>Before the Common Era</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Before Christ</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read <ja>紀元後</ja> already, because then you'll just have to remember the <ja>前</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Until about what year before Christ did the dinosaurs exist?
context_sentences.ja: きょうりゅうがいたのは、紀元前何年ごろまでですか。

context_sentences.en: This Koichi keeps insisting that he's a man who time traveled from Ancient Rome.
context_sentences.ja: 今日のコウイチは、自分は紀元前の古代ローマからタイムスリップしてきた男だって言いはってきかないんです。

context_sentences.en: If time machines existed, I would want to go to 3000 BCE.
context_sentences.ja: もしタイムマシーンがあったなら、紀元前三千年紀に行ってみたいな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>晩ご飯</ja> is "dinner"? Well, that word is so 12 hours ago. This is morning and in the <kanji>morning</kanji> your <kanji>meal</kanji> is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: <ja>朝</ja> is like the vocab version, <ja>あさ</ja> and <ja>ご飯</ja> is like the word you learned, <ja>ごはん</ja>.

context_sentences.en: My nose twitched when I smelled the delicious breakfast.
context_sentences.ja: 朝ご飯の美味しそうなにおいに鼻がひくひくしました。

context_sentences.en: Our family always has rice, miso soup, omelets, and dried fish for breakfast.
context_sentences.ja: わが家の朝ご飯は、ご飯と味そしる、玉子やきに干し魚と決まっています。

context_sentences.en: "Did you just tell Koichi about his surprise breakfast party?" "Oh! I didn’t know it was a surprise."
context_sentences.ja: 「ねぇ、さっきコウイチにサプライズ朝ごはんパーティーの事を教えたでしょ？」「えっ！サプライズだったなんて知らなかった！」

data.meaning_mnemonic: イギリス means "Great Britain" or "United Kingdom." So what is a "Great Britain person?" You guessed it — a <vocabulary>British person</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Often times, when two kanji come together to form a kanji compound (or jukugo), you use the on'yomi readings. This is similar to that, though instead of another kanji it's a foreign word. This pattern works with almost any country as well. Just add <ja>人</ja> to a country name and you've described the people who live there. You'll see more of these before you're finished here.

And since <ja>人</ja> has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: 

As with all words for nationalities, the <ja>人</ja> here is pronounced <ja>じん</ja>. All nationalities, including <vocabulary>Brit</vocabulary>s, love <reading>jean</reading>s (<ja>じん</ja>)!

context_sentences.en: That British person with the straight nose speaks in a nasal voice.
context_sentences.ja: あの鼻すじの通ったイギリス人は、鼻にかかった声で話します。

context_sentences.en: Apparently, this British person hasn't tried ume vinegar before.
context_sentences.ja: このイギリス人は、梅ずを飲んだことがないそうです。

context_sentences.en: I got a friend request from a Brit I don't know.
context_sentences.ja: 知らないイギリス人から友達申請が来たよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that <ja>泣く</ja> is to cry, so you can probably guess that <ja>泣き</ja> is just "cry." You've also seen how <ja>虫</ja> is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a <vocabulary>crybaby</vocabulary>?
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>泣く</ja> and <ja>虫</ja>. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.

context_sentences.en: Hey, crybaby Ko-chan. Here comes a tunnel you like.
context_sentences.ja: 泣き虫コウちゃーん、ほら、コウちゃんの好きなトンネルだよーっ！

context_sentences.en: Only Koichi knows Viet is a crybaby.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチだけがビエトが泣き虫だということを知っている。

context_sentences.en: My daughter's high fever doesn't seem to be coming down. She is usually a crybaby, but it seems like she doesn't even have energy to cry now and I'm worried.
context_sentences.ja: 娘の高熱が中々下がりません。普段は泣き虫なんですが、今は泣く元気も無いようで、心配です。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cry</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound of <vocabulary>crying</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>sob</vocabulary>. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab words <ja>泣く</ja> and <ja>声</ja>. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!

context_sentences.en: When I heard my wife sobbing, I finally realized that she'd had a tough day.
context_sentences.ja: つまの泣き声を聞いて、ようやくつらい一日をすごしたんだなということが分かりました。

context_sentences.en: I overheard Koichi talk with Viet in a tearful voice.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチがビエトに泣き声で話しをしてるのを聞いてしまったんだよね。

context_sentences.en: I understand that hearing a crying baby can be unbearable, but that doesn’t mean that people shouldn’t bring their babies on the train, right?
context_sentences.ja: 赤ん坊の泣き声を聞くのは耐え難いことだというのは分かるのですが、だからって赤ちゃんを電車に乗せない方がいいってことにはならないと思うのですが？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>night</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at night. That is <vocabulary>dinner</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Tonight's supper is salted, sun-dried flounder.
context_sentences.ja: 今日の晩ご飯のオカズは、天日干しで作ったカレイの干物です。

context_sentences.en: Before the dinner, I drank down a glass of beer in one gulp.
context_sentences.ja: 晩ご飯の前に、ビールを一気にグビッと飲み干しました。

context_sentences.en: Koichi almost went insane when he saw how messy the kitchen was after supper.
context_sentences.ja: 晩ご飯の後の散らかった台所を見て、コウイチは気が狂いそうだった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious <vocabulary>lunch</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words <ja>昼</ja> and <ja>ご飯</ja>. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.

context_sentences.en: My boyfriend started drooling when he saw some cute girl even though we were eating lunch together.
context_sentences.ja: かれったら、私と一しょに昼ご飯を食べている時に、他のかわいい女を見て鼻の下をのばしてたんだから。

context_sentences.en: Oh no, I was thinking of doing okonomiyaki for lunch, but I forgot that we ran out of sauce.
context_sentences.ja: あ、まずい！昼ご飯はお好みやきにしようと思ってたのに、ソースが切れてるのわすれてた。

context_sentences.en: Oh no, I just burned the toast again. That was the last slice. Now I have to find something else for lunch.
context_sentences.ja: しまったぁ、またトーストを焦がしちゃったよ。最後の一枚だったのに。何か別のものを昼ご飯に探さなくちゃ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that an <ja>お願い</ja> is a request, and that <ja>事</ja> is a "thing" or "action." So, this is a "request action," in a sense. A better way to say that is <vocabulary>one's wish</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>, because that's what you're doing when you do the action of requesting something.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words <ja>お願い</ja> and <ja>事</ja>. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too.

context_sentences.en: I think your prayers will be answered soon.
context_sentences.ja: あなたの願い事は、きっとすぐにかなうと思います。

context_sentences.en: When Koichi goes to sleep he always keeps a piece of paper with his wishes written on it nearby.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチはいつも、願い事を書いた紙をそばにおいてねます。

context_sentences.en: Japanese people visit shrines on important occasions not only to make wishes but also to offer thanks.
context_sentences.ja: 日本人は、人生の節目節目に、願い事だけでなく感謝の気持ちを伝えるために、神社を訪れます。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something is making one thing the <kanji>same</kanji> as another <kanji>inside</kanji> a <kanji>period of time</kanji>. You'll see this word on computer-ish things a lot. This is <vocabulary>syncing</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: When I was syncing my iPhone, it turned off and I was a little freaked out.
context_sentences.ja: iPhone同期中に電源が切れて軽くあせった。

context_sentences.en: I wonder why Dropbox always freezes while syncing photos.
context_sentences.ja: Dropbox、いつも写しん同期中にフリーズしてしまうのはなぜ。

context_sentences.en: It will probably show up soon. My Evernote is syncing right now.
context_sentences.ja: たぶんもうすぐ反映されると思う。私のエバーノート今同期中だし。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji too! You must have been praying to the kanji Gods at the local <ja>お寺</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Apparently, the body of someone who died accidentally was found at the temple last night.
context_sentences.ja: 昨夜、あのお寺で変死体が発見されたらしいよ。

context_sentences.en: I lived next to a temple when I was a child and it was really convenient for studying Buddhism.
context_sentences.ja: 子どものころ、寺のとなりに住んでいたので、仏教の勉強には大変都合が良かったんです。

context_sentences.en: I held a birthday party at one of the local temples in Japan. We got kicked out pretty quickly. I should have known that a temple wasn’t a good place to have a rock concert.
context_sentences.ja: 日本の地元のお寺で誕生日会を開いたんだけど、すぐに追い出されちゃった。お寺ってロック・コンサートをやる場所じゃないってこと、知っておけばよかったんだけど。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Hopefully you know the word <ja>期待</ja> by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it <vocabulary>to expect</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word <ja>期待</ja>, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

context_sentences.en: I'm quite susceptible to illness, so don't expect too much from me.
context_sentences.ja: 病気がちな体しつなので、あまり期待しないでください。

context_sentences.en: The wife was anticipating that her husband would come back with clementines on their anniversary.
context_sentences.ja: つまは、けっこん記念日にはおっとがみかんを買ってかえってくるものだと期待していた。

context_sentences.en: I'm anticipating Valentine’s chocolate from girls other than my mother this year.
context_sentences.ja: 今年は母親以外の女子からのバレンタインのチョコレートを期待しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>回転</ja> is "rotation" and you probably know what <ja>すし</ja> is (gets rendaku'd in this word to <ja>ずし</ja>). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's <vocabulary>rotating sushi</vocabulary>, also known as <vocabulary>conveyor belt sushi</vocabulary>. Look it up if you don't know what it is.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>回転</ja>, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.

context_sentences.en: A new conveyor belt sushi shop opened up.
context_sentences.ja: 新しく回転ずしのお店がオープンした。

context_sentences.en: The sushi-go-round turned at 32 rotations per second.
context_sentences.ja: その回転ずしは、毎秒三十二回転していました。

context_sentences.en: Hey, still not ready? I'm too hungry. We'll go to rotating sushi without you, if you still aren't ready in three minutes.
context_sentences.ja: ねぇ、まだ準備出来てないの？お腹ペコペコなんだけど。三分以内に準備出来なかったら、先に回転寿司に行っちゃうからね！

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>回転</ja> means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes <vocabulary>to rotate</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to revolve</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from <ja>回転</ja> of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

context_sentences.en: This Koichi doll revolves around this Viet doll at high speed by clockwork.
context_sentences.ja: このコウイチ人形は、このビエト人形の周りを、時けい仕かけで高速で回転します。

context_sentences.en: Michael can make the ball spin without touching it.
context_sentences.ja: マイケルは、ふれずにそのボールを回転させることができます。

context_sentences.en: The swivel chair rotates like this.
context_sentences.ja: この回転椅子はこんな風に回転するんだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Is the <kanji>evidence</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> enough to convince me? Is this really <vocabulary>proof</vocabulary> enough?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: We have verification that Kristen is truly the well-protected daughter of a respectable family.
context_sentences.ja: クリステンが正真正めいの箱入りむすめであることが証明された。

context_sentences.en: Do you have something to verify your identity?
context_sentences.ja: 何か身分を証明できる物は持っていますか？

context_sentences.en: Would you rather receive some sort of certificate proving you finished the TextFugu and WaniKani courses?
context_sentences.ja: テキストフグとワニカニの各コースが修了するごとに、修了証明書のようなものが受け取れた方がいいですか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>weekday</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day of the week</vocabulary>, as in "Monday" or "Tuesday." You'll be learning those on level 18, but first you should learn <ja>曜日</ja> to get you prepared.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for <ja>曜</ja> and the kun'yomi reading for <ja>日</ja>. You've learned both of these already, but be careful because <ja>ひ</ja> of <ja>日</ja> changes to <ja>び</ja> here.

context_sentences.en: Why don't we make Wednesday the day we try speaking Japanese at the speed of native speakers?
context_sentences.ja: 水曜日は、ネイティブが話すスピードで日本語を話す日にしませんか？

context_sentences.en: What day of the week is today?
context_sentences.ja: 今日って何曜日だっけ？

context_sentences.en: The bottom line is that we have to finish this Japanese assignment by Friday.
context_sentences.ja: 肝心なのは、この日本語の課題を金曜日までに終わらせなければならないということだ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you have a <kanji>feeling</kanji> (<ja>気持ち</ja>) that is <ja>いい</ja> (that means "good" by the way), you have a <vocabulary>good feeling</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab word <ja>気持ち</ja>, so if you know that (or the vocab words <ja>気</ja> and <ja>持ち</ja>) you should be A-okay on this one. Maybe even <vocabulary>feeling good</vocabulary> about it?

context_sentences.en: This down duvet feels really good.
context_sentences.ja: この羽毛ぶとん、気持ちいい。

context_sentences.en: Doesn't it feel good to have a clean house?
context_sentences.ja: 家がきれいだと気持ちいいよね！

context_sentences.en: This massage feels good. I'm enjoying this good pain!
context_sentences.ja: このマッサージ、気持ちいい。このいた気持ちよさがたまらない。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This takes the <kanji>luck</kanji> meaning from the kanji. Think of it this way: If you're "carrying" you're going to create your own luck. Now nobody will mess with you, kanji gangstah. You carry guns and have a ton of <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary> because of it.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji! How... shall I say... <vocabulary>luck</vocabulary>-filled?

context_sentences.en: If you're lucky, you may be able to meet Koichi from Tofugu.
context_sentences.ja: 運が良ければ、トーフグのコウイチに会えるかもね。

context_sentences.en: I was just lucky.
context_sentences.ja: たまたま運が良かっただけだよ。

context_sentences.en: I might have run out of luck though, and I don't want to use it up on something like this.
context_sentences.ja: こんなことで使い果たしたくはないけど、これで運を使い果たしちゃったかも。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <vocabulary>Kansai</vocabulary> region of Japan is the Southern Central part of Japan. It actually <kanji>connects</kanji> the East side of Japan (at least back in the day) to the West side, making it the "connection to the west." For our purposes, though, we should call it "Kansai."
data.reading_mnemonic: Urgh, what a confusing reading! The <ja>西</ja> is <ja>さい</ja> instead of <ja>せい</ja>. Readings like this just make you want to <reading>sigh</reading> (<ja>さい</ja>), no?

context_sentences.en: Michael has been consolidating his position as the number one comedian in Kansai.
context_sentences.ja: マイケルは、関西一の芸人としての地位を固めつつある。

context_sentences.en: I heard that people from Kanto and people from Kansai don't get along well. Is it true?
context_sentences.ja: 関東の人と関西の人って折が合わないって聞いたんですが、本当ですか。

context_sentences.en: This guy is a total noob in Kansai, so we’ll have to show him around.
context_sentences.ja: こいつは関西は完全に初心者だから、俺らが案内してやらないとな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>heights</kanji>. What a nice area to be, it's where everyone wants to live! This magical place is <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary>. Heard of it before? It's a city, and kind of the rival to Tokyo.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, but then again so are people from Osaka (just kidding, Osakazens!). The <ja>大</ja> reads like <ja>おお</ja> from <ja>おおきい</ja>. Then, <ja>阪</ja> uses the kun'yomi reading as well, which you didn't learn. That being said, doesn't this kanji look like <ja>坂</ja>, which also means slope? Well, it shares a kun'yomi reading as well, so if you've seen <ja>坂</ja> you can apply that reading over to here, making <ja>おおさか</ja>. Then again, if you know this word means <vocabulary>Osaka</vocabulary> you probably can figure out how to write it too. Don't forget the double <ja>おお</ja> though!

context_sentences.en: I heard that not many cars obey the speed limit in Osaka, is that true?
context_sentences.ja: 大阪では、せいげん速度を守って走る車は少ないと聞いたんですが、本当ですか？

context_sentences.en: I was so excited about the Osaka trip that I totally neglected my studies.
context_sentences.ja: 大阪旅行が楽しみすぎて、勉強がすっかりお留守になってしまっていました。

context_sentences.en: I’m afraid I won’t be able to make it next Wednesday. What about going to Osaka next Thursday instead?
context_sentences.ja: あいにくですが、来週の水曜日はちょっと都合がつかないんです。代わりに来週の木曜日に大阪に行くってのはどうでしょうか？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right side</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word <ja>右</ja> by now. Also, the <ja>側</ja> reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word <ja>側</ja>.

context_sentences.en: The steering wheels of Japanese cars are usually on the right side.
context_sentences.ja: 日本の自動車のハンドルは通常右側にあります。

context_sentences.en: There's a lot of salt in the right-hand drawer of Koichi's desk.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチのつくえの右側の引き出しには、塩がたくさん入っています。

context_sentences.en: We took a picture of a ghost. Look. There is a little girl who wasn’t there on the right in the picture. Can you see her?
context_sentences.ja: 心霊写真を撮っちゃったの。ほら。この写真の右側に、その場にはいなかった幼い女の子が写ってるのよ。分かる？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left side</vocabulary>. Simple as that.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab <ja>左</ja> and add it to <ja>側</ja> to have yourself <ja><reading>ひだりがわ</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: Everybody stands on the left side on this escalator I guess.
context_sentences.ja: このエスカレーターでは、みんな左側に立っていますね。

context_sentences.en: They drive on the left in Japan the same as they do in England.
context_sentences.ja: 日本は、イギリスと同じで、車は左側通行ですよ。

context_sentences.en: When sleeping, I prefer to lie down on my left side.
context_sentences.ja: 寝る時は、左側を下にして横になる方が好きです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With <ja>側</ja> you've already learned it. With <ja>内</ja> you've also already learned the reading. Combine them together and you have <ja>うちがわ</ja>. In case you've forgotten, here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky <ja>うち</ja> portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "<reading>Oo, chee</reading>se!" (<ja>うち</ja>) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"

context_sentences.en: I'll wait for you inside Resona Bank.
context_sentences.ja: りそな銀行の内側で待っています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> with <kanji>salt</kanji> in it is <vocabulary>salt water</vocabulary>. Best not to drink <ja>塩水</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know <ja>塩</ja>'s from the kanji and you know <ja>水</ja>'s from the vocab word <ja>水</ja>. Combine them together and you have <ja><reading>しおみず</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: I thought I had a good nose, but I couldn't tell which one was salt water.

context_sentences.en: The temperature itself isn't that high, but the sun's rays are really strong, so why don't you take some salt water to prevent heatstroke?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>taste</kanji> of <kanji>salt</kanji> is a <vocabulary>salty taste</vocabulary> (it's also when something <vocabulary>tastes salty</vocabulary>).
data.reading_mnemonic:
The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of <ja>塩</ja> (you learned the reading with the kanji) and <ja>味</ja> and you have yourself <ja><reading>しおあじ</reading></ja>.

If you happen to be a cooking show fan, you might also hear the on'yomi reading of this word - <ja><reading>えんみ</reading></ja>. This word can also be read as <ja><reading>しおみ</reading></ja>, which has more or less the same meaning as the primary reading you learned.

context_sentences.en: Maybe I could've used more salt.
context_sentences.ja: もっと塩味を利かせてもよかったかもね。

context_sentences.en: Lightly-salted potato chips aren't that popular.

context_sentences.en: "Hey! I heard that if I make salty jello for Koichi, I’ll get a free TextFugu account." "It’s better if you don’t believe that. I think it’s a lie!"

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the <ja>けつ</ja> is shortened to <ja>けっ</ja> as <ja>つ</ja>s often are when in a situation like this.

context_sentences.en: The pharmacy department is absent today, eh?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The people who <kanji>exit</kanji> their <kanji>seat</kanji>s at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true <vocabulary>attendance</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the <ja>しゅつ</ja> gets changed to <ja>しゅっ</ja>, as many <ja>つ</ja>s do in this situation.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an <vocabulary>empty seat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>open seat</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The particle <ja>に</ja> here is a clue that this word is an adverb. An adverb describes actions, so what's a <kanji>normal</kanji> action? It's one you're <vocabulary>always</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>constantly</vocabulary>, doing. That's what makes it normal!
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this:

I <vocabulary>always</vocabulary> <reading>tune</reading> (<ja>つね</ja>) my violin, but today I didn't tune it. So, now I sound terrible. Imagine how terrible my untuned violin sounds, compared to how it always sounds.

context_sentences.en: My mom didn't always seem to be attracted to my dad.

context_sentences.en: Lately, I'm always asleep by ten.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>s are what you have in your regular <vocabulary>everyday life</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>normal life</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>discerning</kanji> is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are <vocabulary>common sense</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>? Because someone used a <reading>hose</reading> (<ja>ほす</ja>) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...

context_sentences.en: I told you not to put the sweater in the dryer but to hang dry it.
context_sentences.ja: セーターはかんそうきに入れないで、干してねって言ったじゃない。

context_sentences.en: I think that comedian has definitely been deprived of any chance to appear on television recently. Don't you agree?
context_sentences.ja: あの芸人、ぜっ対最近干されてるよね。

context_sentences.en: I wanted to put our laundry outside to dry, but our clothesline just broke.
context_sentences.ja: 洗濯物を外に干したかったんだけど、物干し竿が壊れちゃって。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>天気</ja> is weather (and how <ja>天</ja> often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have <vocabulary>dry weather</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Because of the continuous, twenty-nine day drought, Fugu is about to dry out.
context_sentences.ja: れんぞく干天日数が二十九日をむかえ、フグは干からびるすん前だった。

context_sentences.en: The long, cruel dry weather killed all the vegetables in my field.
context_sentences.ja: 無じ悲な干天がつづき、はたけのやさいが全てかれてしまった。

context_sentences.en: The supply of bacon Koichi got for the starving workers was like a welcome rain after a drought.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチから腹ペコの社員への差し入れのベーコンは、まさに干天の慈雨だった。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>ford</kanji>ing a stream, and you suddenly feel <kanji>dry</kanji> feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary>. It's an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary> trying to stop you from fording.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
