context_sentences.en: Koichi is definitely not the type of boss to interfere, but it seems he likes meddling in what Viet is doing for some reason.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、どんなことにも干渉してくるタイプの上司ではありませんが、何故かビエトが何をしているのかについては口出しするのが好きなようです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add <vocabulary>phantom</vocabulary> to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>s.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a <reading>mob of Roshi</reading>s (<ja>まぼろし</ja>). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

context_sentences.en: You'll be able to see apparitions if you take this drug.
context_sentences.ja: この薬を飲むと、幻が見えますよ。

context_sentences.en: I caught a phantom fish!
context_sentences.ja: 幻の魚をつかまえたぞ！

context_sentences.en: After a series of ecstasy filled visions of Salmon, Fugu finally remembered she had been dead for 12 years, and he realized he was seeing an illusion.
context_sentences.ja: 恍惚状態の中でサーモンの幻を何度も見た後に、フグはようやく彼女が12年前に死んだことを思い出し、自分が幻を見ていたことに気づいた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> you have when you're <kanji>awake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hallucination</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Koichi sometimes has hallucinations while recording podcasts.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは時々、ポッドキャストをレコーディングしている時に幻覚を起こしてしまうんだ。

context_sentences.en: When you watch this video, you have to watch in a well-lit place, not too close to the screen, otherwise I heard you'll have hallucinations.
context_sentences.ja: この映像を見る時は、部屋を明るくしてはなれて見ないと、幻覚が見えてくるらしいよ。

context_sentences.en: Fugu must have been hallucinating from the hallucinogenic mushrooms he ate.
context_sentences.ja: フグは幻覚作用のあるキノコを食べたせいで、幻覚に襲われていたに違いない。

data.meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> that changes your <kanji>concept</kanji> of the world is a big <vocabulary>fantasy</vocabulary> (it's also an <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when it changes your concept of the world, it becomes a total fantasy!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: No matter how old Fugu gets, he still lives in a world of illusion.
context_sentences.ja: フグはいくつになっても幻想の世界の住人なんだな。

context_sentences.en: I sometimes cherish the sweet illusion that Koichi is my son.
context_sentences.ja: 時々、コウイチが自分の息子だというあまい幻想をいだいています。

context_sentences.en: My older brother maintains the ridiculous fantasy that he is the king of the blowfish.
context_sentences.ja: 私の兄は、自分が河豚の王だという馬鹿げた幻想を持ち続けている。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!

context_sentences.en: There’s gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe.
context_sentences.ja: くつの底にガムがついてるよ。

context_sentences.en: It's ridiculous to go swimming in the bottomless swamp.
context_sentences.ja: 底無しぬまに泳ぎに行くなんて、無茶だよ。

context_sentences.en: Thanks to Tofugu, I'm now fluent in Japanese. I thank them from the bottom of my heart.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグのお陰で、日本語がペラペラになりました。心の底から感謝しています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bottom of one's heart</vocabulary>. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from <ja>心底</ja>? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
data.reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!

context_sentences.en: I'm sincerely happy that Koichi's incurable disease actually has been cured.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの不治の病が治って、心底うれしいよ。

context_sentences.en: I think Koichi hates me from the bottom of his heart.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチには心底からきらわれていると思います。

context_sentences.en: There are a lot of nice people in my new department and I feel tremendously relieved.
context_sentences.ja: 新しい部署、優しい人がいっぱいで、心底ホッとしたよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>river bottom</vocabulary>, also known as the <vocabulary>riverbed</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for <ja>底</ja>!

context_sentences.en: The river is deep around there, so be careful.
context_sentences.ja: あの辺りは川底が深いので気を付けてください。

context_sentences.en: There's a lot of sand on the bed in this river.
context_sentences.ja: この川は、川底にかなりのすながたまってしまっています。

context_sentences.en: "What did you do during Golden Week, Salmon?" "I lost my wedding ring in a river, so I was looking for it. It took me three days, but I finally found it buried in the riverbed."
context_sentences.ja: 「サーモンはゴールデンウィーク期間中何してたの？」「結婚指輪を川で無くしちゃって、ずっと探してたの。三日もかかったけど、ようやく川底に沈んでいる指輪を見つけたわ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>建てる</ja> is "to build." This is similar to that, but it's the version where you're not doing the building. Something is just getting built. That's why this word is <vocabulary>to be erected</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to be built</vocabulary>. You can recognize that because of the <ja>つ</ja>, which tells you that <reading>two</reading> (<ja>つ</ja>) guys are building the building while you watch. So you're not doing it, they are, and it's just happening.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is shared with <ja>建てる</ja>, so if you know <ja>建てる</ja> then you should be able to read this word as well.

context_sentences.en: New high-rise buildings are being built one after another in Tokyo.
context_sentences.ja: 東京には、新しい高そうビルがぞくぞくと建っています。

context_sentences.en: Koichi's bronze statue was erected at the White House.
context_sentences.ja: ホワイトハウスに、コウイチのどうぞうが建ちました。

context_sentences.en: Salmon and I are discussing buying a pre-built home at the north end of the beach, but it’s a little expensive for us.
context_sentences.ja: サーモンと僕は、浜辺の北端に建つ家を買おうと相談してるんですが、ちょっと私達には値段が高いんですよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>thing</kanji> you <kanji>build</kanji> is a <vocabulary>building</vocabulary>. There aren't too many other things you build, at least not to this extent.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is a bit weird. It's kun'yomi readings across the board, meaning your knowledge of <ja>建てる</ja> hopefully can come into play here. A building is something you build, so how do you say "to build"? It's <ja>建てる</ja> (<ja>たてる</ja>). Since it's a thing you build, it's a <ja><reading>たてもの</reading></ja>. This reading is a bit confusing, but hopefully after a while you'll get it if you get it wrong too many times! Maybe if you think about the building you're in and call it a <ja>建物</ja> a few times it'll sink in better?

context_sentences.en: This is very nicely designed building, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: すてきなデザインの建物ですね。

context_sentences.en: It's only been a year since it was built, but this building is pretty dirty already, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: 建てられてからまだ一年しかたってないのに、あの建物はもうずい分よごれているね。

context_sentences.en: "I’d like to go see the building with you so when would be convenient for you?" "Well, I’ll adjust my schedule accordingly."
context_sentences.ja: 「あなたとその建物を一緒に見に行きたいと思うのですが、いつがご都合よろしいですか？」「ええっと、あなたのご都合に合わせますよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: What you <kanji>build</kanji> up in <kanji>front</kanji> of other people is your public image. This is your <vocabulary>public behavior</vocabulary>, how you act around others you don't really know. This concept is surprisingly important in Japan, so you'll hear it often enough despite being such a strange concept in other places. You'll have to think of this like you're building buildings of personality in front of you. These show off who you are on the outside, but it protects what's on the inside.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty strange. It's a lot like <ja>建物</ja> in that it's read as <ja>たて</ja>, which is like the word <ja>建てる</ja> even though the <ja>て</ja> isn't showing here. So, you'll have to remember it's read like <ja>建てる</ja> but the <ja>て</ja> gets pushed into the kanji.

context_sentences.en: Viet is good at separating his public and private selves.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは本音と建前を使い分けるのが上手い。

context_sentences.en: Our official stance is that you can't see a doctor here without a letter of reference.
context_sentences.ja: しょうかいじょうが無いとここの医者にみてもらえないというのは建前です。

context_sentences.en: It’s often said that "the contrast between one’s personal feelings and public behavior" is a characteristic unique to Japanese culture, but that exists all over the world.
context_sentences.ja: よく「本音と建前」は日本独特の文化だと言われますが、実際は世界中に存在します。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> you also have <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your <vocabulary>love</vocabulary> isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant <reading>Koi</reading> (<ja>こい</ja>) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!

context_sentences.en: I haven't truly fallen in love yet.
context_sentences.ja: 私はまだ、恋をしたことがない。

context_sentences.en: Don't you think Salmon got prettier? I think it's because she's a woman in love, don't you?
context_sentences.ja: サーモンちゃん、なんかかわいくなったよな。恋する女って感じじゃない？

context_sentences.en: I can’t get Fugu out of my head! Is there love in the air?
context_sentences.ja: フグのことが頭から離れないの。これって恋の始まりなのかな？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fault</kanji> of <kanji>romance</kanji> isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unrequited love</vocabulary>. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: My heart was broken because of my flat, red nose.

context_sentences.en: I’m heart broken and it really hurts. I want to go shopping to get rid of my stress. Why don’t we go to the sale this weekend and have lunch together?

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>love</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> that is <vocabulary>self love</vocabulary>. You’ll mostly see this word as part of the set phrase <ja>ご自愛下さい</ja>, which is used in emails and the like to remind the recipients to be good to themselves. Other variations include <ja>ご自愛くださいませ</ja>, <ja>ご自愛を</ja>, and <ja>ご自愛のほどを</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>defeat</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary>, but also <vocabulary>to be unsuccessful</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "<reading>Yah, Boo</reading>" (<ja>やぶ</ja>) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!", you reply back. "Yah boo", they say again.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you <reading>cuss yuri</reading> (<ja>くすり</ja>) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Maybe you didn't know this, but if you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the cuss words first. <ja>くそ</ja> is sh*t / garbage, though it's not really a "bad" word in Japanese like it is in English. So, what is your <kanji>nose</kanji> sh*t? It's your <vocabulary>snot</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>boogers</vocabulary>. Ewwww, stop eating them!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. <ja><reading>はなくそ</reading></ja>.

context_sentences.en: I saw a man with an aquiline nose pick his boogers and put them in the nostrils of a sleeping man with a short nose.
context_sentences.ja: かぎ鼻の男が、ほじくり出した鼻くそを、ねむっている低い鼻の男の鼻の穴に入れるのを見ました。

context_sentences.en: I'm collecting the snot I pick out with my finger on a tissue.
context_sentences.ja: 指でほじくり出した鼻くそをティッシュの上に集めています。

context_sentences.en: Fugu accused me of being selfish. Talk about an eye crust laughing at a booger.
context_sentences.ja: フグが僕のことを自分勝手だって責めるんだ。目くそ鼻くそを笑うだよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know the <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>nose</kanji>? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the <vocabulary>tip of the nose</vocabulary>. Time to cut off the rest, next!
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With <ja>鼻</ja> you learned that with the kanji. With <ja>先</ja> you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

context_sentences.en: You got mustard at the tip of your nose.
context_sentences.ja: 鼻先にマスタードがついてるよ。

context_sentences.en: That police dog started twitching the tip of its nose and sniffing at the stranger.
context_sentences.ja: その警察犬は、鼻先をひくひくさせて、見知らぬ人のにおいをかぎ始めた。

context_sentences.en: When Fugu saw that the tip of Salmon’s nose was so red, he found it very cute.
context_sentences.ja: フグはサーモンの鼻先が赤くなってるのを見て、とても可愛いと感じた。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Try singing a <kanji>nose</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji>. How does it sound? Like <vocabulary>humming</vocabulary> perhaps?
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a <ja>鼻</ja> is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know <ja>鼻</ja>'s reading from the kanji (<ja>はな</ja>) and you know <ja>歌</ja>'s reading from the vocabulary word <ja>歌</ja> (<ja>うた</ja>). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, <ja>はなうた</ja>.

context_sentences.en: Koichi was humming while making his nose swell.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチは、鼻をふくらませながら、鼻歌を歌っていた。

context_sentences.en: Viet was happily riding his bicycle while humming.
context_sentences.ja: ビエトは鼻歌まじりで楽しそうに自転車に乗っていました。

context_sentences.en: LMAO! You are just terrible at humming.
context_sentences.ja: 爆笑！お前鼻歌下手すぎだっつーの。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>nose</kanji> with <kanji>blood</kanji> is a nose with a <vocabulary>nosebleed</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>bloody nose</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know <ja>鼻</ja>'s reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of <ja>血</ja> as well. Put them together and you have <ja>はなち</ja>, though you want to change the <ja>ち</ja> to <ja>ぢ</ja>. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as <ja>はなじ</ja>. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

context_sentences.en: If you have a mustache it'll be a pain if your nose bleeds, right?
context_sentences.ja: 鼻の下にひげをはやしていると、鼻血が出た時に大変ですね。

context_sentences.en: Excuse me. I just need a quick word with you. Your nose is bleeding.
context_sentences.ja: すみません。ちょっと一言、言わせてもらいたいんだけど、あなた、鼻血が出てますよ。

context_sentences.en: I tried to rush onto the train, but the doors closed, squished my nose and made it bleed.
context_sentences.ja: 電車に駆け込み乗車をしようとして鼻が挟まれて、鼻血が出ました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>下品</ja> is "crude" and "vulgar" - this is obviously the opposite. This is <vocabulary>elegant</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: Sometimes my mom reveals her elegant mannerisms.
context_sentences.ja: 母は時々上品な仕草を見せる時があります。

context_sentences.en: My friend gave a speech using elegant language at a Mrs. contest.
context_sentences.ja: 私の友達はミセスコンテストで上品な言葉づかいでスピーチした。

context_sentences.en: Kanae’s parents have always been very strict in telling her to use a knife and fork elegantly.
context_sentences.ja: カナエはいつも上品にナイフとフォークを使うように両親からキツく言われている。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>大阪</ja> (Osaka)? This is the <kanji>dialect</kanji> they speak, making this word <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you know how to read <ja>大阪</ja> you can just add <ja>弁</ja> to it and be able to read the whole thing, though maybe not in <vocabulary>Osaka dialect</vocabulary>. Okay, fine, it's probably the same thing in Osaka dialect.

context_sentences.en: That supervisor with the Osaka dialect always takes forever to get to the point, it's very annoying.
context_sentences.ja: あの大阪弁の上司は、いつも前おきが長いので、うんざりします。

context_sentences.en: I've put the past with my ex with the Osaka dialect behind me already.
context_sentences.ja: 大阪弁のかれ氏とのかこは、もう忘れました。

context_sentences.en: "Don’t worry. I won’t tell anyone that you speak with the Osaka dialect. Your secret is safe with me." "Thanks."
context_sentences.ja: 「心配しないで。君が大阪弁を喋るってことは誰にも言わないよ。秘密は守るよ。」「おおきに！」

data.meaning_mnemonic: Do you remember <ja>関西</ja>, which is the Kansai region of Japan? Well, they have their own <kanji>dialect</kanji>, and it is <vocabulary>Kansai Dialect</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab <ja>関西</ja>'s reading and the kanji reading of <ja>弁</ja>, combined.

context_sentences.en: I heard poop is called baba in Kansai dialect.
context_sentences.ja: 関西弁で、ウンチのことをババというらしいです。

context_sentences.en: It's really scary when people complain in Kansai dialect, isn't it?
context_sentences.ja: 関西弁で文句を言われると、かなりこわいよね。

context_sentences.en: He said things to me like, “I hate you” and “go home” and it sounds awful, doesn’t it? But I actually thought it was pretty cool because he said it all using Kansai dialect. It was really hot.
context_sentences.ja: 彼、私に向かって、「お前のこと嫌いやねん」とか「帰れや」とか言ったのよ。ひどいでしょ？でもさ、実は関西弁で言われたもんだから、ちょっと格好いいなんて思っちゃったんだよね。何か、すごいセクシーだったの。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>earth</kanji> day of the week is a day you find yourself close to the earth. Either you found you drank too much on Friday, so on this day's morning you're laying right on the ground of earth. Or, maybe you just want to sleep in after staying up late on Friday. Either way, this day you lay close to the earth is <vocabulary>Saturday</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <ja>曜日</ja> as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>Sun</kanji> day of the week is <vocabulary>Sunday</vocabulary>. Doesn't get much easier than that for you. Lucky!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The "<kanji>moon</kanji>" day of the week is <vocabulary>monday</vocabulary>. Why? Because "Moon" is pretty much just "Mon," right?
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <ja>曜日</ja> as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>tree</kanji> day of the week is <kanji>Thursday</kanji>. Tree day comes after water day (which is Wednesday, for Water-Wednesday!). Trees need water to grow, which is why the tree comes right after the water.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <ja>曜日</ja> as well.

context_sentences.en: The gas pipe cracked on Thursday.

context_sentences.en: I think I'm gonna do the laundry on Thursday.
context_sentences.ja: 洗たくは、木曜日にしようと思ってます。

context_sentences.en: On Thursday, do you want to do something fun like making a snowman or building an igloo?

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a day of the week. You know this because it has <ja>曜日</ja> in it. But what day of the week is it? The <kanji>water</kanji> day of the week is where the water flows from. Think of your entire week as a big hill, with Wednesday (hump day) being in the middle. This hump is a hill. What originates from hills? Water! That's why Water day is <vocabulary>Wednesday</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word <ja>曜日</ja> as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>留学</ja>, which means "study abroad"? Do you also remember <ja>学生</ja>, which is "student"? This word is like those two words mashed together (they share a <ja>学</ja>), making it a "study abroad student." What's a better way to say that? How about <vocabulary>exchange student</vocabulary>!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: That international student always forgets to tie his shoes.

context_sentences.en: That exchange student is always photobombing pictures of my boyfriend and me. It’s kind of annoying.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>笑う</ja> is "to laugh." This is a noun version of that, though it's not "a laugh," (that's <ja>笑い</ja>). Add <ja>お</ja> to that and you have the thing that makes you laugh. It's <vocabulary>comedy</vocabulary>. It's the <vocabulary>joke</vocabulary> that's elevated with <ja>お</ja> because it made you laugh SOOOOO much. Haha!
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same <ja>笑う</ja> or <ja>笑い</ja>. It's also the same as what you learned with the kanji.

context_sentences.en: When Michael got a job at Tofugu, he moved to Portland, Maine by mistake. It's still a funny story we laugh about to this day.

context_sentences.en: Koichi gets intensive comedy training from Michael every day.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember <ja>荷物</ja> and how it means "baggage" or "luggage." Add a <kanji>hand</kanji> to it and you have <vocabulary>hand baggage</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hand luggage</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: If you know <ja>荷物</ja> and you know <ja>手</ja>, then you should be able to Voltron the two together into one mega reading.

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <ja>証明</ja>'s reading will also be helpful.

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know that <ja>笑う</ja> is "to laugh." This is the noun version, because the <ja>う</ja> in <ja>笑う</ja> turns to <ja>い</ja> (so don't confuse this as an adjective). What is the noun version of "to laugh"? It's <vocabulary>a laugh</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>笑う</ja>, so just make sure you know that so you can know this as well.

context_sentences.en: It’s not like you to cry at movies. You always laugh really hard when there are any serious scenes in them.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>task</kanji> of <kanji>borrow</kanji>ing something is when you're <vocabulary>borrowing</vocabulary> something. It's also when you get a <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: My debt has now reached one million yen.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>borrow</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to borrow</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Dude, can I borrow your <reading>ca</reading>r (<ja>か</ja>)? Please?

context_sentences.en: I want to skim the scum off the top, so can I borrow your ladle for a second?
context_sentences.ja: アクを取りたいので、ちょっとお玉を借りてもいいですか？

context_sentences.en: I borrowed one of your loose‐leaf sheets of paper, Kristen.
context_sentences.ja: クリステンのルーズリーフ、一枚借りたよ。

context_sentences.en: "I’m sorry I lost the romance novel I borrowed from you." "Don’t worry about it. I won’t need it anymore anyway. I have a girlfriend now."

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>money</kanji> (and <kanji>gold</kanji>) you <kanji>borrow</kanji> is your <vocabulary>debt</vocabulary>. Be sure to pay it back before the yakuza come for you.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The <ja>しゃく</ja> gets shortened to <ja>しゃっ</ja> though, so beware. Just think of that like the little bit that you lost to the yakuza, because they weren't happy you didn't pay back your debt. *cut*

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>borrow</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji> you are <vocabulary>renting a house</vocabulary>. Also, this is a <vocabulary>house for rent</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but in this case the second kanji can be read with either the on'yomi or kun'yomi. This uses a less common kun'yomi of <ja>家</ja>, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're <vocabulary>renting a house</vocabulary>, someone has to give you the keys and let you in and stuff. You're only renting, after all. So when they let you in they'll say, "Here's a <reading>shack</reading> for <reading>yah</reading>! (<ja>しゃくや</ja>) Enjoy!"

By the way, in the secondary reading <ja>しゃっか</ja>, the <ja>しゃく</ja> goes to <ja>しゃっ</ja>. This reading is only used in contexts like legal documents, though, so <ja>しゃくや</ja> is likely to be far more useful for most people.

context_sentences.en: You can't borrow money on a rented house.
context_sentences.ja: 借家をたん保にお金を借りることは出来ませんよ。

context_sentences.en: "Tenants' Rights" simply means you have the right to rent a house, right?
context_sentences.ja: 借家けんって、単じゅんに、「借家するけん利」のことでしょう？

context_sentences.en: I’m trying to talk to Salmon about renting a house instead of buying one, but she kind of keeps skirting the issue.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. That means it does not take a direct object. Something comes off. Something is removed. No direct object here. That's why this verb means <vocabulary>to come off</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be removed</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as <ja>取る</ja>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>News</kanji> that you <kanji>announce</kanji> becomes a <vocabulary>report</vocabulary>. When someone announces news on a topic, they are giving you a report on the <vocabulary>information</vocabulary>.

<ja>報告</ja> is a report given by someone after they've done some investigation or research into the topic. It can be used for class presentations on a topic or a report given to your boss. This differs from <ja>報道</ja>, which is a report released by news organizations.

data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are what you'd expect except for <ja>きつ</ja> getting shortened to <ja>きっ</ja> and <ja>茶</ja>, which has this strange <ja>さ</ja> reading. To remember that it's <ja>さ</ja> instead of <ja>ちゃ</ja>, think of this <vocabulary>tea house</vocabulary> you're going in. You think it's nice and pleasant, and it is for a while... until someone starts working a <reading>saw</reading> (<ja>さ</ja>) outside, ruining the atmosphere. BEWWEEEEHHHEEEHHHHHE gatatatatatat BWEEEHEEE.

context_sentences.en: Does Tofugu have any data-handling rules?

context_sentences.en: Well, I’d like to stop by later to exchange information on the WaniKani project, if it’s okay with you.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>news report</kanji> that covers things <kanji>beforehand</kanji> (before they happen) is a <vocabulary>forecast</vocabulary>. For example, a weather forecast is a <ja>天気予報</ja>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: It slipped my mind that the forecast had said that it would rain in the afternoon.
context_sentences.ja: 今日は午後から雨の予報だったことをすっかり忘れていました。

context_sentences.en: The weather girl said the forecast is calling for hot weather, starting tomorrow.
context_sentences.ja: お天気お姉さんは、明日から暑くなるって予報してたけどね。

context_sentences.en: According to the weather forecast, this year Canada is expecting snow all year round.
context_sentences.ja: 天気予報によると、カナダは今年はずっと雪が降る見通しです。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>news report</kanji> so you could try to say "to news report" but that doesn't make sense. What does make sense is "<vocabulary>to report on</vocabulary>," however.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't seem like it's the kanji's on'yomi reading, but it is. What an oddity! Do you think it's worth doing a news report on it? Koichi, reporting in on this strange reading that is readable by you right now. Signing off.

context_sentences.en: The entire United States wept when they broke the news that Superman had died.
context_sentences.ja: スーパーマンの死去が報じられ、全米が涙した。

context_sentences.en: I felt relieved when they reported that Koichi is safe.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの無事が報じられて、胸をなで下ろしました。

context_sentences.en: Tofugu covered an exclusive interview with Hatsune Miku.
context_sentences.ja: トーフグは、初音ミクの独占取材を報じた。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>News</kanji> travels down the <kanji>road</kanji> by way of a <vocabulary>news report</vocabulary>.

<ja>報道</ja> specifically refers to information put out by news organizations or the press in the form of newspaper articles, radio or television broadcasts, etc. Notice that it's different from <ja>報告</ja>, which is more general and means the reporting of information by anyone.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: All of my coworkers knew about the news report already.
context_sentences.ja: 同りょう達は、みんなその報道のことをすでに知っていました。

context_sentences.en: How will this terrorist attack be reported in Japan?
context_sentences.ja: 今回のテロのことは、日本ではどのように報道されていますか？

context_sentences.en: According to the news report, twenty fish were transported to a local hospital after a pileup that occurred early this morning.
context_sentences.ja: 報道によると、本日早朝に起きた玉突き事故で、20匹の魚が地域の病院へ運ばれたそうだよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>守る</ja> is "to protect," right? This is like that, but it's the noun version. It's not really "a protection," though it kind of is. What things can you wear to protect you from things like bad luck, demons, and ancient aliens? That would be an <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>. You'll see these kinds of things sold at temples and such.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is like that of <ja>守る</ja>, so if you know the reading of that word you should be able to read this one as well.

context_sentences.en: How long can I have this charm for?
context_sentences.ja: このお守り、どのぐらいお借りしていてもいいですか？

context_sentences.en: It seems I forgot to pack my amulet.
context_sentences.ja: お守りを入れるのを忘れちゃったみたい。

context_sentences.en: You shouldn’t wear multiple lucky amulets at the same time. It could bring you bad luck instead.
context_sentences.ja: たくさんのお守りを同時に付けない方がいいですよ。逆に不幸をもたらすかもしれないですからね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>留守</ja> means "absence" or "away from home"? Well, now that you're absent from your home, it's someone else's  turn to come to your home and take care of it. This person is the <vocabulary>caretaker</vocabulary>, someone who's <vocabulary>looking after one's house</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing <ja>留守</ja> will be important as well.

context_sentences.en: I took a housesitting job for 20,000 yen a day.
context_sentences.ja: 一日二万円で留守番の仕事を引き受けた。

context_sentences.en: In America, it's illegal to let small kids look after their homes alone.
context_sentences.ja: アメリカでは小さい子どもだけで留守番させるのはい法です。

context_sentences.en: If you want to travel for two months, you need to hire a caretaker.
context_sentences.ja: ２ヶ月間旅行したければ、留守番を雇う必要があります。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>correct</kanji> way to <kanji>sit</kanji> is this way: <vocabulary>traditional Japanese sitting</vocabulary> (this is when you sit on your legs and your feet, kneeling). You can also call it <vocabulary>seiza</vocabulary>. Learning the reading will help with the meaning.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: How can you sit seiza for that long?
context_sentences.ja: 何でそんなに長い間正座できるの？

context_sentences.en: I thought Koichi would make me do seiza, but he was as generous as a Buddhist priest and excused me for being late.
context_sentences.ja: 正座させられると思っていましたが、仏僧のように心が広いコウイチは、私のちこくを許してくれました。

context_sentences.en: I knelt in seiza for so long during the Buddhist memorial service that my legs were completely numb.
context_sentences.ja: 法要の間長時間正座をしていたので、足がすごく痺れています。

data.meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>sit</kanji> and do <kanji>zen</kanji> you are probably doing <vocabulary>zen meditation</vocabulary>. Hummmmm.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: The Zen meditation reached its climax there.
context_sentences.ja: 座禅は、そこでクライマックスに達した。

context_sentences.en: I'd definitely love to experience Zen meditation when I travel to Kyoto.
context_sentences.ja: 京都に旅行に行ったら、ぜひ座禅の体験をしてみたいなあ。

context_sentences.en: My friend is a monk and he does Zen meditation sessions in his temple. He told me that we could not only relax but also attain enlightenment and be free of desires and attachments with Zen meditation.
context_sentences.ja: 私の友達はお坊さんで、自分のお寺で座禅の会を開いています。彼は、座禅によって、リラックスできるだけでなく、欲望や執着心が無くなる悟りの境地に至ることもできると教えてくれました。

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sit</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is probably going to be a <vocabulary>seat</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: This seat's cushion is really comfy.

context_sentences.en: I didn't know that I had to make reservations for seats.

context_sentences.en: The moment Salmon leaned across the seat to kiss Fugu in the car, the traffic light turned green.

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>silver</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> isn't some crazy kingdom where the king sits upon a silver seat. It is a famous place in Tokyo. Perhaps if you read the reading it will become more apparent what the meaning is (since they're the same). This silver seat place is <vocabulary>Ginza</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: It took forever to get through the traffic around Ginza.
context_sentences.ja: 銀座付近で、じゅうたいをぬけるのにすごく時間がかかった。

context_sentences.en: When my cousin was walking in Ginza, she was interviewed by a TV crew.
context_sentences.ja: いとこは銀座を歩いていた時に、テレビ局からインタビューを受けました。

context_sentences.en: If you want to find a clever lover, maybe you should go to Ginza, Tokyo.
context_sentences.ja: もし賢い愛人を見つけたいのなら、東京の銀座に行くのがいいかもね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>弁当</ja> is "bento"? Well, the <ja>弁</ja> in this word comes from that, so pretend it means "bento." Then, when you have a <kanji>train station</kanji> to go along with the bento, you have a <vocabulary>train station bento</vocabulary>. As you might think, a train station bento is just a bento that's sold at a train station. Easy!
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I was so busy I forgot to buy a train station bento.
context_sentences.ja: いそがしすぎて、駅弁を買うのを忘れてました。

context_sentences.en: One fun thing to do during domestic trips in Japan is to compare various station bento.
context_sentences.ja: 日本国内の旅行の楽しみの一つは、色々な駅弁を食べくらべることです。

context_sentences.en: Oh, you forgot to bring the onigiri? We’ll have to buy a station bento for lunch.
context_sentences.ja: あっ、おにぎりを持ってくるのを忘れたの？じゃあ、お昼は駅弁を買わなくちゃいけませんね。

data.meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You have your bow and you use it to shoot things, sure, but you've also covered it in candy so you can eat it when you're waiting out in the woods waiting for a buck to come by. You lick your candy bow and say: "<reading>yummy</reading>!" (<ja>ゆみ</ja>). Imagine the taste of your bow. What taste would make you say yummy?

context_sentences.en: We can't find Koichi's bow anywhere.
context_sentences.ja: コウイチの弓がどこにも見当たらないんだ。

context_sentences.en: You have to stabilize your upper body to draw the bow.
context_sentences.ja: 弓を引くには、まず上半身を安定させなくてはいけません。

context_sentences.en: Yeah, Lawson is open 24/7, but, you know, I don’t think they carry bows and arrows.
context_sentences.ja: うん、ローソンは確かに二十四時間営業だよ。でもさぁ、あのー、多分弓と矢は置いてないと思うよ？

data.meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>path</kanji> of the <kanji>bow</kanji>. This is <vocabulary>archery</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: I came to the conclusion that kyudo is difficult.
context_sentences.ja: 弓道はむずかしいという結ろんに達しました。

context_sentences.en: Why are Japanese bows for kyudo so powerful?
context_sentences.ja: 日本の弓道の弓って、どうしてそんなに強いの？

context_sentences.en: "What are you working on?" "Japanese Archery."
context_sentences.ja: 「一生懸命何しているの？」「弓道だよ。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>forget</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to forget</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Wait, what <reading>was</reading> (<ja>わす</ja>) the reading? I <vocabulary>forget</vocabulary>... What was it?

context_sentences.en: Sorry, Kanae. We all totally forgot about how much effort you put into it.
context_sentences.ja: ごめんね、カナエちゃん。みんなカナエちゃんがどれだけ努力したのかすっかり忘れちゃってたんだ。

context_sentences.en: I almost forgot Koichi's face.
context_sentences.ja: 危うくコウイチの顔を忘れる所だったよ。

context_sentences.en: Forget about it. It’s water under the bridge.
context_sentences.ja: もう忘れなって。過ぎてしまったことは今さらどうにもならないんだから。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Time to get <kanji>together</kanji> and <kanji>forget</kanji> the <kanji>year</kanji>... what a terrible year, good thing a new one is coming. This get together is a <vocabulary>year end party</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: As for what happened at today's year end party, I'll just let it go.
context_sentences.ja: 今日の忘年会であった出来事は、忘れる事にします。

context_sentences.en: I'm already really forgetful, so I don't need a so-called "forget the year party."
context_sentences.ja: 元々忘れっぽいんで、私には「忘年会」は必要ありません。

context_sentences.en: In many Japanese companies, new workers are required to do a short performance at an end of the year party.
context_sentences.ja: 多くの日本企業では、新入社員は忘年会で一発芸を披露しなくてはならない。

data.meaning_mnemonic: Something <kanji>below</kanji> your <kanji>writing</kanji> isn't what you want to necessarily publish to the world. It's below your writing, after all. This is merely a <vocabulary>rough draft</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading, as you can maybe guess from the hiragana sticking out. If you know the readings of the words <ja>下</ja> and <ja>書く</ja> separately, you should be able to combine them into one reading. Just don't forget the rendaku here!

context_sentences.en: In order to write a good article, it is important to make a rough draft.
context_sentences.ja: いい記事を書くためには下書きをすることが大事です。

context_sentences.en: Did you know Koichi keeps the rough draft for a poem he wrote in high school in his desk drawer in the office?
context_sentences.ja: コウイチのオフィスのつくえの引き出しには、高校の時に書いた自作の詩の下書きが大切にしまってあるって知ってる？

context_sentences.en: I wonder if Aya usually makes a rough pencil draft first or if she just draws freehand.
context_sentences.ja: アヤって、いつも最初に鉛筆で下書きしてるのかな。それとも、下書き無しで絵を描いてるのかな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: To <kanji>insert</kanji> what you <kanji>write</kanji> into something is <vocabulary>to write in</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to fill in</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>書く</ja> and <ja>入れる</ja>. Combine those two words to get the reading of this word.

context_sentences.en: If you could fill in your social security number here in this document, I can take care the rest.
context_sentences.ja: この書類のここに社会保証番号を書き入れてもらえれば、あとは全て上手くやっておきますよ。

context_sentences.en: I wrote in my name on the marriage certificate.
context_sentences.ja: けっこん証明書に名前を書き入れました。

context_sentences.en: I want Koichi to make a Tofugu notebook so that we can write our Japanese study schedules in it.
context_sentences.ja: 日本語の学習予定を書き入れるトーフグ手帳をコウイチに作ってもらいたいな。

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>writing</kanji> (kind of like how <ja>見方</ja> is the way of seeing). A better way to say this though would be to call it <vocabulary>penmanship</vocabulary>, though. How's your <ja>書き方</ja>? Mine is terrible.
data.reading_mnemonic: This uses the kun'yomi readings from the vocab words <ja>書く</ja> and <ja>方</ja>. So as long as you're okay with those, you can apply that knowledge over here.

context_sentences.en: I can't remember how to write this kanji.
context_sentences.ja: この漢字の書き方が思い出せない。

context_sentences.en: Why doesn't Tofugu have an app to teach the ways of writing?
context_sentences.ja: トーフグにはどうして書き方を教えるアプリが無いんですか？

context_sentences.en: I am bored out of my mind with studying hiragana penmanship.
context_sentences.ja: 平仮名の綺麗な書き方を勉強することには、心底飽き飽きしてるんだよね！

data.meaning_mnemonic: If you take your <kanji>writing</kanji> and <kanji>fix</kanji> it, you are taking your writing and rewriting it. This word means <vocabulary>to rewrite</vocabulary>, because the fixing is really heavy, so regular revisions won't do.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings come from <ja>書く</ja> and <ja>直す</ja>. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!

context_sentences.en: Please change the protagonist to Viet instead of Koichi and rewrite this story.

context_sentences.en: "Do you think we have enough time to rewrite this?" "I don’t think so."
context_sentences.ja: 「これを書き直す時間があると思う？」「私はそうは思わないね。」

data.meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>flat object</kanji>s but <kanji>what</kanji> amount of flat objects? This word is asking that question: "<vocabulary>how many flat objects</vocabulary> are there?" If this doesn't make sense, think back to words like <ja>何回</ja> or <ja>何年</ja> which ask "how many ____" just like this one.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

context_sentences.en: About how many tickets have you sold so far?

data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wash</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You have <vocabulary>to wash</vocabulary> <reading>a ro</reading>ck (<ja>あら</ja>) you found. It looks shiny, but you can't tell until you wash it.

context_sentences.en: When you return home, please wash your hands and gargle.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wash</kanji> that washes <kanji>car</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>car wash</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Don't confuse this with the same-sounding <ja>戦車</ja> though... unless you're washing your <ja>戦車</ja> in a <ja>洗車</ja>...

context_sentences.en: If there's someone out there who wants to wash Koichi's car, please email us at hello@tofugu.com.

data.meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>zen</kanji> <kanji>temple</kanji> is just what it sounds like, a <vocabulary>zen temple</vocabulary>. Sounds nice.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the two words <ja>禅</ja> and <ja>寺</ja> put together. The <ja>てら</ja> gets changed to <ja>でら</ja>, though.

In terms of when it's pronounced <ja>ぜんじ</ja>, if you put this word onto the end of the name of a <ja>禅寺</ja> the pronunciation changes to <ja>ぜんじ</ja>. It makes sense - it's more like a jukugo word that way (not that the original isn't, but you can see the separation of words coming together which gives the hint that it's a kun'yomi combo reading). Anyways, you may need a zen temple to keep your mind pure enough to remember this, but it's a good thing to keep in mind if you can.

context_sentences.ja: あの禅寺、さいむちょうかの会社のかぶに投しをして、痛い目にあったらしいよ。

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>私</ja> can mean <kanji>private</kanji> and how <ja>大</ja> is the first half of <ja>大学</ja>? Well, combine those together and you have the shortened version of <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary>.

You went to a specific <vocabulary>private college</vocabulary> just to study <reading>dye</reading>s (<ja>だい</ja>). You're so into dyes that you decided to go to this extremely expensive <vocabulary>private university</vocabulary> that specializes in dyes. Good for you!

It also means <vocabulary>to forgive</vocabulary>, in that "I'll permit it this time... but only this time." Look out for <ja>許さない</ja> in TV shows, too. The kanji itself means <kanji>try</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to try to do something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to attempt something</vocabulary>.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>renew</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be renewed</vocabulary>. Like most verbs ending in <ja>まる</ja>, this is an intransitive verb, meaning it happens all on its own. Nobody is doing the renewing, it's just happening (as renewing often does).
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You probably learned this reading with this verb's transitive other half <ja>改める</ja>, but here's a mnemonic anyway just in case: 

<vocabulary>To be renewed</vocabulary> you decide to go to a spa. You get in a bathtub and they pour in <reading>a lotta</reading> (<ja>あらた</ja>) leeches and eels to help you to be renewed. Feel the fear. There are a lot of them! Alternatively, you can imagine them pouring in a lotta Maru cats, because that's way fuzzier.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a food pretty specific to Japan, making it a slightly weird one to learn. You have a <kanji>Japanese Plum</kanji>. Then you have <kanji>dry</kanji>. So when the Japanese plum is dried, it's not a dried plum (that would be too easy), it is a <vocabulary>pickled plum</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>pickled ume</vocabulary>. If you know the name of this food, you can call it by that too: <vocabulary>umeboshi</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this one, like the meaning, is kind of strange. It's the kun'yomi readings, so apologies in advance for that. You have <ja>うめ</ja> plus <ja>ぼし</ja>, which comes from <ja>干す</ja> though the <ja>し</ja> is stuffed inside the <ja>干</ja> for some reason. It's also rendaku'd. Basically, everything is all screwed up, so you know, deal with it. This food is awesome, and common, so you have to learn it. I guess the pickling process has mangled the reading of this word. At least it tastes good.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a tough one. When you <kanji>compare</kanji> <kanji>examples</kanji> (in this case of numbers) you are figuring out the <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>ratio</vocabulary>. A ratio, for example, has one number on top of another. They are examples being compared. Same with proportions. Without two things to compare, proportion doesn't make sense. That's why when you compare examples, you are dealing with proportions or ratios.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>mix</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to mix something</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to stir something</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to blend something</vocabulary>. This is when you're doing the mixing. You can remember this because "<reading>there</reading> (<ja>ぜる</ja>) is much mixing to be done so it's best if you just do it because nobody else will."

The connotation for this word is you can't distinguish the things you're mixing, like combining paints, which become one mixed color that isn't two separate colors anymore.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're doing mixing like your <reading>ma</reading> (<ja>ま</ja>) taught you, which is why when you do the mixing things get done around here a lot faster.

You can also use the level 5 vocab <ja>交ぜる</ja> to help you remember as it has the same meaning and reading!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. This is when something is entangled on its own (you're not directly doing the entangling). You can remember this because of the <ja>む</ja>, which is you saying <reading>mo</reading>ve (<ja>む</ja>) out of the way, I have to take care of this entanglement mess that just happened on its own.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The entanglement mess you're fixing is a couple of kids that got their hair tangled up. They were doing some sparring in their <ja><reading>から</reading>て</ja> class and one thing led to the other and suddenly both their hair was entangled together.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is a little confusing for someone who didn't grow up with the Japanese language. You have <kanji>fifty</kanji> <kanji>sound</kanji>s. Then, they're in a certain <kanji>order</kanji>. So, these fifty sounds are the Japanese syllabary. That's hiragana / katakana, probably from back in the day when there were more sounds than there are now. So, the "fifty sounds in order" makes up <vocabulary>aiueo order</vocabulary>, where the "aiueo" is <ja>あいうえお</ja> representing the five columns.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji itself means <kanji>overthrow</kanji> or <kanji>collapse</kanji>, and this verb is transitive, like most verbs ending in <ja>す</ja>, so you are doing those things to something else. So, this verb means things like <vocabulary>to knock over</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to knock down</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>to bring down</vocabulary>.

This word can be used to talk about physically knocking something over, as well as bringing something or someone down, like a government.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You use the power of the <reading>Tao</reading> (<ja>たお</ja>) to do all of your knocking down. Imagine yourself contemplating Tao philosophy, then using those pleasant thoughts to knock everything over around you. BLAM!

data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're having this crazy <vocabulary>dream</vocabulary>. The dream allows you to do anything you want. Every time you ask "hey, can I do this?" The answer is always "<reading>you may</reading>" (<ja>ゆめ</ja>). Think of some things you'd want to do if you could do anything. Ask permission and get this answer in your imagination.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>obstruct</kanji>, so what is the verb vocab version? It's <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You try <vocabulary>to obstruct</vocabulary> a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am <reading>Sama(n)tha</reading>!" (<ja>さまた</ja>) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!

context_sentences.en: I heard that company is trying to hamper Tofugu's success.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>incur</kanji> so you'd think this would mean "to incur," but it doesn't. This is <vocabulary>to put on a hat</vocabulary>. Yep, it's the verb that's made for putting on hats. So, think of it this way. You "<kanji>incur</kanji>" a hat when you go <vocabulary>to wear a hat</vocabulary>. Pretty weird but you'll get it if you put on your thinking cap.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The hat that you put on is way too heavy for you. It falls off your head and hits the ground with a loud <reading>KABOO</reading>M (<ja>かぶ</ja>). You put it back on and pull it down tight, but this time it pulls you to the ground with an even louder KABOOM!

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading for this word is pretty weird. It's different than the <ja>嫌い</ja> word you will see in this level too. It is <ja><reading>いや</reading></ja>, so when you think of something you dislike, just think "<reading>iyah</reading>, I dislike it." Also, think about that <vocabulary>eww</vocabulary> feeling it gives you when you think of the thing you dislike most.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
You know that <ja>嫌</ja> means <kanji>dislike</kanji> and this vocab word means the same thing: <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hate</vocabulary>!

Though this word is an adjective in Japanese, it usually makes sense to translate it as a verb in English, because of the difference in sentence structure. However, a more literal translation would be <vocabulary>dislikable</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>detestable</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Of all the things out there to <vocabulary>dislike</vocabulary> the thing I dislike the most is the <reading>killer</reading> (<ja>きら</ja>) of people. People should never kill people.

data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for <ja>尻</ja> from the kun'yomi <ja>しり</ja> you learned already. Here it gets shortened to <ja>しっ</ja>. The reading for <ja>尾</ja> is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The animal with the best <vocabulary>tail</vocabulary> in the world is the <reading>po</reading>lar (<ja>ぽ</ja>) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun form of <kanji>disaster</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>misfortune</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When a <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary> strikes, you start moaning and groaning. Say it along with me: "<reading>Wahhhhh! Zaahhhh! Waahhhh!</reading>" (<ja>わざわ</ja>). Be careful of the <ja>い</ja> on the end, it can be tricky and make you think it's an adjective when it's a noun.

data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You sort of did learn this reading with the vocabulary word <ja>煙</ja>, but this one is just different enough where we thought we should make a mnemonic for this one:

data.meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Stand</kanji>ing and <kanji>enter</kanji>ing are both <ja>禁止</ja> (prohibited). If you see this sign, it's essentially saying <vocabulary>do not enter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no entry</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic:
The reading for <ja>立入</ja> is a bit strange, but it might help you to know that it can also be written <ja>立ち入り</ja>. The <ja>立ち</ja> is the same one you learned with <ja>立ち飲み</ja> and the <ja>入り</ja> is the reading you learned with <ja>入り口</ja>. In our version of the word, the hiragana isn't visible (it's sort of pushed into the kanji), but the word is still pronounced the same way: <ja>たちいり</ja>.

And <ja>禁止</ja> doesn't have any weirdness going on, so at least you have that!

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji <ja>達</ja> pluralizes things sometimes. So, when you have a <kanji>plural</kanji> amount of a <kanji>person</kanji> you have more than one person, you have <vocabulary>people</vocabulary>.

Take note! When using this word, you want to attach it to the type of "people" you are talking about. For example, <ja>あの人達</ja> (those people over there). Other examples: <ja>男の人達</ja>, <ja>その人達</ja>, <ja>向こうの人達</ja>, etc. You don't use this by itself, instead you use it with something describing what kind of people you're talking about.
data.reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi readings of the kanji. The readings come from the word <ja>人</ja> and the <ja>だち</ja> of <ja>友達</ja>, though now it's <ja>たち</ja> because it hasn't been rendaku'd. You like to <reading>touch</reading> (<ja>たち</ja>) people, you perv.

context_sentences.en: These people are really talkative, eh?
context_sentences.ja: この人達、みんな本当によく舌が回るよね。

data.meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>add</kanji> and this word is the verb version of that: <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary>.

This is a transitive verb, meaning that you are doing the adding to something else. You add a nose to your snowman, for example.
data.reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You decide <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary> something and then <vocabulary>to add</vocabulary> something else, and you end up with quite a <reading>qua</reading>ntity (<ja>くわ</ja>) of things. Just keep adding and adding forever. What a huge QUANTITY you now have!

data.reading_mnemonic:

data.meaning_mnemonic:
Remember <ja>広い</ja>? Well this is like that, except a verb. When something does the action of getting <kanji>wide</kanji>, it means <vocabulary>to spread out</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to extend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary>.

You already learned <ja>広げる</ja>, which is used when YOU spread something. <ja>広がる</ja>, on the other hand, means that something spreads out all on its own. It's worth mentioning that lots of intransitive verbs end in <ja>がる</ja>, and this is no exception. Just think how about a girl (<ja>がる</ja>) you know can do everything all by herself. She never needs help from anyone else.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>広い</ja>, too, so as long as you knew that you knew this reading as well.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Throw Something Out Of Order

data.meaning_mnemonic: You know how <ja>乱れる</ja> is "to be in disorder"? Well, now you're the one causing this. So, by doing this you are going <vocabulary>to put in disorder</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to throw out of order</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to disturb</vocabulary> whatever it is. Just imagine all the people who will try to <reading>sue</reading> (<ja>す</ja>) you for your actions.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have <ja>混じる</ja> (to get mixed up in), <ja>混ぜる</ja> (to mix), <ja>混ざる</ja> (to get mixed), and now this: <ja>混む</ja>, <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary>. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other <ja>混</ja> words? Just think of how cows <reading>muuuuu</reading> (<ja>む</ja>) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary>.
data.reading_mnemonic: Hey, <reading>come</reading> (<ja>こむ</ja>) out of that crowd of cows. It's going <vocabulary>to be crowded</vocabulary> in there.

context_sentences.en: The roads are pretty busy at that time, aren't they?

context_sentences.en: Farmers' markets get quite crowded around noon, so I try to go shopping as early in the morning as possible to avoid the crowds.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This one is a little strange. You have <ja>混む</ja> (To Be Crowded), <ja>混ぜる</ja> (to mix), <ja>混ざる</ja> (to get mixed), and now this: <ja>混じる</ja>, <vocabulary>To Get Mixed Up In</vocabulary>. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine <reading>Je</reading>sus (<ja>じ</ja>) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers.
data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as (almost) all the other <ja>混</ja> verbs. All about mamamamama!

data.reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as <ja>混乱</ja> so no reason for you <vocabulary>to be confused</vocabulary>, right?

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. You can differentiate this from <ja>減る</ja> because with this one, you are the one that is going to be doing the decreasing. The <reading>rush</reading> (<ja>らす</ja>) of decreasing something fills your veins.

data.meaning_mnemonic: This is like <ja>続く</ja> except for now you're the one doing the continuing. Unfortunately, there's no good way to differentiate the two "continues" using just the meaning, but you can think of it this way: With <ja>ける</ja>, you really <reading>care</reading> about continuing this thing so you are continuing it (doing the action of continuing). With <ja>く</ja> you're just like "that's <reading>coo'</reading> if it continues, but I don't really care...

data.meaning_mnemonic: Remember how <ja>自動詞</ja> was "intransitive verb"? Intransitive verbs are when something just happens. You aren't doing the action to them. This word, however, is the other kind. A <vocabulary>transitive verb</vocabulary> is when you are directly doing something to something else. That's why it has <kanji>other</kanji> in there, because it's a <kanji>verb</kanji> (<ja>動詞</ja>) you do to an<kanji>other</kanji> thing, directly.

data.meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<ja>てき</ja> and <ja>かたき</ja>, however, have slightly different nuances. <ja>てき</ja> simply means “enemy”, whereas <ja>かたき</ja> typically refers to someone you hold a deep grudge against, often on behalf of another.

data.meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be solved</vocabulary>. You know that this is the version where something just unties on its own (you're not doing the untying) because you don't have a <reading>care</reading> (<ja>ける</ja>) in the world. You just watch things getting untied and don't do it yourself.
data.reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In fact, while you're sitting there with no cares, waiting for things to become untied, you stare down at your <reading>toe</reading> (<ja>と</ja>).
